revision.comment: added link to Downing College website to commemorate 70th anniversary of metriculation
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Alan Norman Howard |birth_date = 16 March 1929 |birth_place = [[Norwich]], [[England]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Cambridge]], [[England]] |education = [[City of Norwich School]],
[[Downing College Cambridge]] |alma_mater = [[Downing College, Cambridge]] |nationality = British |spouse = Grace Elizabeth (née Lee) m. 1954 d. 2008;
Lydia (née Bentley) m. 2008 |children = Jonathan Lee,
Julie Elizabeth |occupation = [[Nutritionist]] and [[Philanthropist]] |known for = Development of the science behind [[The Cambridge Diet]][https://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/biblio?FT=D&date=19771207&DB=EPODOC&locale=en_EP&CC=GB&NR=1493993A&KC=A&ND=5 Dietary Supplement and dietary methods employing said supplement for the treatment of obesity, GB Patent 1493993 19750516] and Chairman of The [[Howard_Foundation_(UK)|Howard Foundation]] |awards = Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]] (FRSC) 1968
Honorary Fellowship of Downing College, Cambridge, 1987.[http://www.dow.cam.ac.uk/people/fellows-directory/honorary-fellows Honorary Fellows of Downing College Cambridge]
Honorary DSc University of Ulster 1996[https://www.ulster.ac.uk/about/governance/secretariat/honorary-graduates#hongrad-h Honorary DSc University of Ulster]
Companion of The Guild of Cambridge Benefactors (12 November 2001)
The Chancellors 800th Anniversary Medal for outstanding philanthropy from the Guild of Cambridge Benefactors 2009[https://www.cam.ac.uk/news/the-chancellor’s-medal-for-outstanding-philanthropy University of Cambridge News 22 July 2009] }} '''Alan Howard''' gained a MA in natural sciences[[Natural Sciences (Cambridge)]] and PhD in [[immunology]] at [[Downing College Cambridge]]. He then trained as a nutritionist at the Medical Research Council's Dunn Nutritional Laboratory[https://www.mrc-ewl.cam.ac.uk/about-us/history/ History of the Dunn] also in [[Cambridge]]. His lifelong research interests are in the field of [[nutrition]], initially in the nutritional relationships associated with [[coronary heart disease]] and the treatment of [[obesity]] and latterly into eye and brain nutrition.{{Cite journal | author = Power R, Coen RF, Beatty S, Mulcahy R, Moran R, Stack J, Howard AN, Nolan JM. | date = January 2018 | title = Supplemental Retinal Carotenoids Enhance Memory in Healthy Individuals with Low Levels of Macular Pigment in A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Clinical Trial. | journal = [[Journal of Alzheimer's Disease]] | volume = 61 | issue = 3 | pages = 947–961 | doi = 10.3233/JAD-170713 | pmid = 29332050 }} His inventions and patents related to [[Very Low Calorie Diets]]{{cite journal | author = Howard AN | title = The historical development, efficacy and safety of very-low-calorie diets | journal = Int J Obes | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 195–208 | year = 1981 | pmid = 7024153 | doi = }} enabled him to establish the [[Howard_Foundation_(UK)|Howard Foundation]].[https://www.howard-foundation.com The Howard Foundation Website] which has made significant donations to Downing College Cambridge, the [[Waterford Institute of Technology]][https://www.fightingblindness.ie/newsx/state-of-the-art-research-facilities-unveiled-at-waterford-indtitute-of-technology-vision-research-centre/ The Howard Laboratory][https://www.wit.ie/news/other/the_vision_research_centre_at_carriganore_house_officially_opens_the_howard The Howard Gate] and in sponsoring continued academic research == Early life and education == Howard passed the [[Eleven-plus]] exam in 1940 and won a place at the [[City of Norwich School]] where he specialised in [[Chemistry]]. His other interests included photography, cycling and ballroom dancing. == Academic career == Howard won a scholarship to [[Downing College Cambridge]] in 1948 to read [[Natural Sciences]] (Chemistry, Physics, Metallurgy and Mathematics). For his PhD he worked in the Department of Medicine with [[Robin Coombs]], a notable immunologist. Howard's thesis was on "The reaction of [[diazonium compound]]s with [[amino-acids]] and [[proteins]] and its application to [[serological]] problems".[http://www.dow.cam.ac.uk/about/downing-college-archive Downing College Archive] Howard's academic career covered periods: *'''1951 to 1959''' demonstrator in practical classes, Part I Organic Chemistry, Chemical Laboratory, Cambridge *'''1954 to 1966''' Supervisor in Chemistry, Downing, Peterhouse and Newnham colleges, Cambridge *'''1954 to 1960''' at the MRC Unit in Nutrition in Cambridge (now the [[MRC Human Nutrition Research]] department founded in 1998) *'''1960 to 1973''' in the Department of Pathology at Cambridge University under [[Austin Gresham]] then Professor of Morbid Anatomy and Histopathology. *'''1965 to 1969''' Lecturer on ‘Lipid Metabolism’ in Comparative Pathology, Part II Course, Cambridge University *'''1973 to 1984''' in the Department of Medicine at Cambridge University under Professor Ivor Mills, a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians[http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/5514 Professor Ivor Mills] *'''1983 to 1992''' as a College Lecturer in Nutritional Research at Downing College Cambridge University.Cambridge University Reporter 20 April 1983 In November 2018, [[Downing College]] commemorated the formal entry of Alan Howard as a student at Downing on 4th November 1948 with an entry on their website[http://www.dow.cam.ac.uk/news/celebrating-70-years-dr-alan-howards-matriculation Celebrating 70 years since Dr Alan Howard's matriculation]. === Early work on atherosclerosis === At the MRC Unit, Howard began working on experimental atherosclerosis. He continued this study while at the Department of Pathology and was secretary for the first International Symposium On Atherosclerosis held in Athens in 1966 and was an editor of the proceedings.{{Cite book | author = Paoletti, Rodolfo. , Miras, C. J. , Howard, Alan N. | date = 1968 | publisher = Basel ; S. Karger | title = Recent Advances in Atherosclerosis. | isbn = 978-3805503839 | url = https://www.karger.com/Book/Home/217290 }} The Proceedings of the XIIth International Symposium on Atherosclerosis held in Stockholm 25–29 June 2000 contain two papers reviewing the significance of the first symposium: "The First International Symposium on Atherosclerosis in Athens 1966" by Alan N. Howard and "The significance and importance of the Athens Symposium" by M. Daria Haust.{{Cite book | author = Sten Stamme, Anders Olsson | date = 2000 | publisher = Elsevier |title = Atherosclerosis XII }} === Early work on obesity === While at the Department of Pathology and through working with another local company, [[Spillers]] Ltd, Howard started doing clinical trials on the high-protein “Cambridge Formula Loaf”.[http://www.gypsycreams.org/2010/03/cambridge-formula-dietary-loaf Cambridge Formula Loaf] Collaborating with several local GPs and using brown bread as a control, he found that people lost more weight while on the Cambridge Loaf together with a low-calorie diet. This work was published in a paper in The General Practitioner {{Cite journal | author = Howard AN, Anderson TB | date = 1968 | title = The Treatment of Obesity with a High-Protein Loaf | journal = The Practitioner | volume = 201 | pages = 491–496 }} (the forerunner of the current [[British Journal of General Practice]] and was used commercially until Spillers closed its manufacturing plant. This led to Howard becoming secretary to the newly formed Obesity Association (aka The Obesity Society of Great Britain and now the Association for the Study of Obesity (ASO){{cite web | url=https://www.aso.org.uk | title=Home |website=aso.org.uk}}). Founded in 1967 to promote obesity research in the UK, the association was chaired by Ian MacLean Baird from the West Middlesex Hospital. In 1968, the society held its first International Symposium in London. The proceedings were edited by Baird and Howard. [https://www.aso.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/ASO-early-history-Ashwell.pdf Early history of the ASO] Howard became secretary and later chairman of The Food Education Society[http://www.foodedsoc.org The Food Education Society] from 1970 until 1990. Howard co-authored a book which was published by the BBC in 1978{{Cite book | author = Al Murrey, Mary Perigoe, Dr Alan Howard | date = 1978 | title = Don't just sit there. | publisher = Barron's Educational Series Inc. | isbn = 978-0-8120-0789-3 }} and was invited to take part in the BBC series ''Don't just sit there'' in July 1980. Howard and [[George A. Bray]] (from the [[University of California]]) organised the first International Congress on Obesity (ICO) which was held at the [[Royal College of Physicians]] in London in October 1974, and attracted over 500 attendees from 30 countries. They were also the founding co-editors of The [[International Journal of Obesity]] (IJO) which began in 1977. These early initiatives led in 1985/86 to the formation of the International Association for the Study of Obesity which since 2014 is known simply as World Obesity[https://www.worldobesity.org/who-we-are/history World Obesity] == The Cambridge Diet (now the Cambridge Weight Plan) == While in the Department of Medicine at Cambridge University, Howard's team ran a longstanding "lipid clinic" at Addenbrookes Hospital between 1973 and 1980.{{Cite book | author = John Marks, Alan Howard | date = 1997 | title = The Cambridge Diet, A manual for health professionals | publisher = Cambridge Export Limited | page = 59 }} This was one of six European centres where the Dutch company [[Organon International]] sponsored research and clinical trials. Howard collaborated with Ian MacLean Baird, then a consultant at West Middlesex Hospital, to devise a low-calorie diet formula designed for morbidly obese patients. This was initially named “Howard's Diet”. Also in 1973, Howard began to direct Dennis Jones, a nutritionist and specialist in food chemistry from Organon, to convert the research concept into a commercially viable formulation. In 1979, it emerged in the US as The Cambridge Diet[https://www.cambridgedietusa.com/about_story.htm The Cambridge Diet USA] The patents of which Howard was a co-inventor were initially licensed to a Californian company, Cambridge Plan International (CPI), who, from 1980, marketed the formula in the US as the 'Cambridge Diet'. This was sold initially by mail order and subsequently through network marketing and a "Cambridge Counsellor" system. Whilst this led to rapid growth, CPI encountered issues[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1983/09/27/the-rise-38/b8604159-b9b6-4818-a54c-175f4cb7bac9/ Washington Post article by Cynthia Gorney][https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=A-gCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=cambridge+diet+Feather+family&source=bl&ots=YMsyKQZs-H&sig=dQP9dvRuCtTiRMczqhSU_r2eJrs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj8q72-_drZAhVMOMAKHTSbDusQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=cambridge%20diet%20Feather%20family&f=false New Yorker Magazine: “The Cambridge Obsession” by Jack Friedman Dec 20 1982] which led to it filing for Chapter 11 administration[[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 Administration]] in 1983. In 1982, Howard, his son Jon and Howard's brother Roger formed the Cambridge Manufacturing Company Ltd. As a result, from 1984 to 1986 there were two competing "Cambridge Diets" in existence, as CPI had separately launched in various countries internationally, including a pre-launch in UK. In 1986 a Howard Foundation company bought out CPI's international rights, and the 'Cambridge Diet' has remained a separate organisation in the US.[https://www.cambridgedietusa.com/about_story.htm Cambridge Diet USA] In 1985, Howard and John Marks[John Marks MA, MD, FRCP, FRCPath, FRCPsych Life Fellow, Girton College, Cambridge] wrote a book “The Cambridge Diet – A Manual for Health Professionals” published by Jonathan Cape in 1986 with a forward by Ivor H Mills, then Professor of Medicine at the University of Cambridge. The forward to the later edition in 1997, published by Cambridge Export Limited, was written by [[John Butterfield, Baron Butterfield|John Butterfield]], formerly [[Regius Professor of Physic (Cambridge)|Regius Professor of Physic]] at the University of Cambridge. The book was translated into Danish as 'Cambridgekuren' for use in the Scandinavian market. From 1985 to the late 1980s, the [[Cambridge Diet]] was strongly promoted in the UK by Howard using direct marketing and thereafter, mainly through distributors, in various Northern European countries and around the world. The Polish website for the Cambridge Weight Plan contains an interview with Dr Howard in which he discusses the background to the Cambridge Diet[http://dieta-cambridge.pl/aboutus/interview.html Interview with Cambridge Weight Plan creator – Professor Alan Howard] In the early 2000s the manufacturing company at Corby, Northants became the group headquarters for the UK and export functions. In 2005 Howard directed that the remaining business be sold through a management buyout. The company changed its name to the Cambridge Weight Plan and continues as a successful employee-owned trust[https://www.cambridgeweightplan.com/about-us The Cambridge Weight Plan] == Later research on [[VLCD]] and [[coronary heart disease]]== Howard established Howard Foundation Research (HFR) in 1986 to carry out scientific research into low-calorie diets under the direction of Stephen Kreitzman. HFR has published numerous scientific papers, most notably a 1993 monograph "The Swansea Trial"{{Cite book | author = Howard, Alan N. , Kreitzman, Stephen N | date = 1993 | title = The Swansea Trial : Body Composition and Metabolic Studies with a Very-low-calorie Diet | publisher = London: Smith-Gordon | isbn = 978-1854630704 | url = https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/003072829 }} edited by Dr S N Kreitzman and Dr A Howard. In 2000 Howard directed Howard Foundation Research Ltd be sold under licence to managers who devised the Lipotrim[http://www.lipotrim.co.uk/about_us/index.htm Lipotrim] programme to allow the formula to be prescribed privately by health practitioners in UK and Ireland. In 1991, Howard established the COAG Trace Elements Laboratory. Based at [[Papworth Hospital]], near Cambridge. The COAG Laboratory ran until 2000 carrying out research into aspects of nutrition and health, especially the prevention of coronary heart disease. When the laboratory closed, the equipment was transferred to the [[University of Ulster]] and the [[Poznan University of Medical Sciences]], for the continuation of research programmes. == Research into macular degeneration and carotenoids == In 1990, Howard started work with Dr Richard Bone[https://physics.fiu.edu/faculty/richard-bone/ Dr Richard Bone] and Dr. John Landrum[https://chemistry.fiu.edu/faculty/john-landrum/ Dr John Landrum] at [[Florida International University]] (FIU). Together they patented a formulation containing [[Meso-zeaxanthin]], [[lutein]] and zeazanthen,{{cite journal| pmc=1872023 | pmid=17498306 | doi=10.1186/1743-7075-4-12 | volume=4 | title=Macular pigment response to a supplement containing meso-zeaxanthin, lutein and zeaxanthin | year=2007 | journal=Nutr Metab (Lond) | page=12 | author=Bone RA, Landrum JT, Cao Y, Howard AN, Alvarez-Calderon F}} manufactured by IOSA in Monterey, Mexico, and sold in Europe as Macucheck and in North America as Macuhealth. Its purpose was to prevent age-related [[macular degeneration]] (AMD). In 2009, Howard began working with the Macular Pigment Research Group (MPRG) at the Waterford Institute of Technology in Ireland. In 2015, the Howard Foundation established Prof John Nolan, principal investigator at the MPRG, as the Howard Chair in Human Nutrition with tenure for 10 years[http://www.macularcarotenoids.org/news/macular_carotenoids_conference_chair_appointed_chair_of_human_nutrition_in_wit_ireland Appointment of John Nolan] In June 2018, Howard and Nolan were co-authors of a paper in the [[Journal of Alzheimer's Disease]] that reported the results of a small 18 month study by the MPRG that showed improvements in the health of Alzheimer's patients{{Cite journal | author = Nolan John, Mulcahy Riona, Power Rebecca, Moran Rachel, Howard, Alan | date = 2018 | title = Nutritional Intervention to Prevent Alzheimer's Disease: Potential Benefits of Xanthophyll Carotenoids and Omega-3 Fatty Acids Combined | journal = Journal of Alzheimer's Disease | volume = 64 | issue = 2 | pages = 367–378 | url = https://content.iospress.com/articles/journal-of-alzheimers-disease/jad180160 | doi=10.3233/jad-180160 | pmid = 29945352 }}. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.howard-foundation.com www.howard-foundation.com] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Howard, Alan}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Nutritionists]] [[Category:Philanthropists]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2016}}
'''Alison Tedstone''' RNutr [[FAfN]] (born April 1961)<ref>[https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/HVdWsGCv0ONuqqKdTEZ_NuEYBbw/appointments Companies House]</ref> is Chief Nutritionist (National Director of Diet & Obesity) at [[Public Health England]] (PHE).<ref>[https://publichealthmatters.blog.gov.uk/author/alison-tedstone/ Public Health England]</ref>
==Early life== She was born Alison Tedstone. She has a BSc and PhD from the [[University of London]]. She conducted research into [[Human nutrition|nutrition]] at the [[University of Oxford]].
==Career== She is a Registered Public Health [[Nutritionist]]. She is a founding fellow of the [[Association for Nutrition]] (AfN).<ref>[http://www.associationfornutrition.org/Default.aspx?tabid=269 AfN]</ref>
===London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine=== She was an academic at the [[London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine]].
===Food Standards Agency=== She joined the [[Food Standards Agency]] (FSA) in 2001, working there until 2010, becoming Head of Nutrition Science.
===Public Health England=== She became Chief Nutritionist at PHE. Work includes the [[National Diet and Nutrition Survey]]. she gives evidence to the [[Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition]] (SACN).
==Personal life== She married Alan Penn in the 1980s in Worcestershire.
==See also== * [[Ailsa A. Welch]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://data.parliament.uk/writtenevidence/committeeevidence.svc/evidencedocument/health-committee/childhood-obesity-strategy/oral/23284.html Government health committee in October 2015]
{{Public health}} {{Diets}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tedstone, Alison}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Academics of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine]] [[Category:British nutritionists]] [[Category:British women scientists]] [[Category:Obesity in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Public Health England]] [[Category:Women nutritionists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fellows of the Association for Nutrition]]
{{nutritionist-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Bailey-Boushay House''', founded June 24, 1992,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailey-boushay.org/bbhandvm|title=BBH & Virginia Mason Seattle, Washington (WA) - Bailey-Boushay House|website=www.bailey-boushay.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> is an inpatient long-term care facility and outpatient day health program for people with [[HIV/AIDS]] in [[Seattle, Washington]], USA. It is an affiliate of [[Virginia Mason Medical Center]]. [[File:Seattle - Bailey-Boushay House 01.jpg|thumb]]
== History == Bailey-Boushay House was the first inpatient [[hospice]] facility for AIDS patients in the [[United States]].<ref name=":0" /> It was founded by Betsy Lieberman and Christine Hurley of AIDS Housing of [[Washington (state)|Washington]] with support from sources including [[Virginia Mason Medical Center]], [[Boeing]], [[Nordstrom]], [[Weyerhaeuser]], the Northwest AIDS Foundation, and an anonymous donation of $100,000 via the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Seattle|Archdiocese of Seattle]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/742517287|title=Gay Seattle : stories of exile and belonging|last=1949-|first=Atkins, Gary,|date=2003|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=0295800992|location=Seattle|oclc=742517287}}</ref> The facility was created as a response to the lack of skilled nursing facilities available for AIDS patients.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailey-boushay.org/body.cfm?xyzpdqabc=0&id=111&action=detail&ref=19|title=Founder/Namesake Profiles Seattle, Washington (WA) - Bailey-Boushay House|website=www.bailey-boushay.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> Its planned location in the [[Madison Valley, Seattle|Madison Valley]] neighborhood drew opposition due to concerns about the proposed outpatient population.<ref name=":1" /> At the time, a member of the facility's opposition was on the board of the [[Seattle Art Museum]]. In May 1990, the Seattle chapter of [[ACT UP]] scheduled a [[Direct action|shutdown]] of the museum construction site to show support for local AIDS patients, but two days before the shutdown the opposition relented.<ref name=":1" /> The facility was named after [[Seattle]] publisher Thatcher Bailey, a founding donor, and his partner Frank Boushay, who died of AIDS in 1989.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailey-boushay.org/body.cfm?id=111&action=detail&ref=18|title=Founder/Namesake Profiles Seattle, Washington (WA) - Bailey-Boushay House|website=www.bailey-boushay.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref><ref name="community.seattletimes.nwsource.com">{{Cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920113&slug=1469992|title=Travel & Outdoors {{!}} Aids Housing Is Dedicated - A First For Nation -- Bailey-Boushay House Was Inspired Through `A Passion For Caring' {{!}} Seattle Times Newspaper|website=community.seattletimes.nwsource.com|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> Bailey-Boushay House was dedicated on January 12, 1992.<ref name="community.seattletimes.nwsource.com"/> By 1992, over 2,000 cases of AIDS had been diagnosed in King County, with 90% of the cases present in [[men who have sex with men]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://respondingtoaidsexhibit.org/category/References-and-resources/|title=References and Resources {{!}} Responding to AIDS|website=respondingtoaidsexhibit.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> In the first years at Bailey-Boushay, patients would often arrive from hospitals only a few days before their death from [[AIDS related complications|AIDS-related complications]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/life/lifestyle/treasure-life-wisdom-from-a-former-aids-nurse/|title='Treasure life': wisdom from a former AIDS nurse|date=2017-02-17|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
In the early 1990s, the photographers Saul Bromberger and Sandra Hoover documented the daily life of Bailey-Boushay patients, and their work was published in [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] magazine on [[World AIDS Day]] in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2014/12/portraits-living-with-aids-at-the-bailey-boushay-house/|title=Photos of the first AIDS hospice center. Get some tissues ready.|work=Mother Jones|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
Every year on [[Valentine's Day]], Bailey-Boushay House used to place hundreds of red balloons on the outside of their facility to officially thank the community for their support.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/slideshow/Daily-News-Gallery-2-14-2004-11592/photo-895032.php|title=Daily News Gallery - 2/14/2004|work=seattlepi.com|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref>
== Current work == As of 2017, due to the significant decrease in death rates from [[HIV/AIDS]] due to [[antiretroviral therapy]], the 35-bed inpatient program at Bailey-Boushay House serves patients with a variety of life-threatening diagnoses, such as [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] and [[Huntington's disease]], providing long-term, respite, and end-of-life care.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailey-boushay.org/aboutbbh|title=About Bailey Boushay House, HIV and AIDS Care {{!}} Seattle, Washington|website=www.bailey-boushay.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> The outpatient day health program serves patients with [[HIV/AIDS|HIV]] who are homeless, and/or capable of living independently in the community but require medication management and social support.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bailey-boushay.org/outpatient-program|title=Seattle Outpatient Program - Bailey-Boushay House, Seattle|website=www.bailey-boushay.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> Bailey-Boushay House plans to open a 50-bed [[Homeless shelter|overnight shelter]] to promote housing stability for its outpatient clients, with a projected opening date of November 1st, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://madisonvalley.org/news/bailey-boushay-house-seeking-funding-to-open-emergency-shelter-for-homeless-clients.html|title=Bailey-Boushay House Seeking Funding to Open Emergency Shelter for Homeless Clients|last=Seattle|first=Madison Valley|website=madisonvalley.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref>
Over the past two years, the Daily Outpatient Program has exploded from 100 outpatients to over 400 outpatients. This fact, combined with the complexities of opening a new overnight shelter for the homeless, is causing prolonged increasing strain to the Daily Outpatient Program, resulting in the loss of events regularly provided to benefit the Outpatients' health and enriching their lives [as of Oct. 2018].
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.baileyboushay.org Bailey-Boushay House], official site * [https://www.motherjones.com/media/2014/12/portraits-living-with-aids-at-the-bailey-boushay-house/ Photos of the First AIDS Hospice Center Tell a Story of Struggle and Resilience], photo essay in Mother Jones magazine, December 2014

{{notability|date=October 2018}} '''Beacon UK''' is a private provider of mental health services launched in the UK in September 2011 by Dr Emma Stanton, a practising NHS psychiatrist at the [[South London and Maudsley NHS Trust]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Five minutes with ... Emma Stanton, chief executive of Beacon UK|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2013/may/24/emma-stanton-chief-executive-beacon-uk|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Guardian|date=24 May 2013}}</ref>
Beacon Health Strategies was established in 1996 in the USA by Elizabeth Pattullo developing publicly funded mental health managed care programs – starting with Boston, Massachusetts. The company does not directly deliver mental health care, but attempts to act as an “integrator”, coordinating mental health services from different health and social care providers to ensure care effectively meets the needs of each person with mental health conditions.<ref>{{cite news|title=A beacon of hope for coordinated care|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/home/innovation-and-efficiency/a-beacon-of-hope-for-coordinated-care/5056818.article#.VQYM0fysVyU|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=18 April 2013}}</ref>
Stanton was named as one of the [[Health Service Journal]]'s most inspirational women in health and one of their Top Innovators. She is a former adviser to Sir [[Liam Donaldson]] and co-founded Diagnosis, a clinical leadership social enterprise. From 2010-11, she had a [[Harkness Fellowship]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Emma Stanton|url=http://www.nursingtimes.net/emma-stanton/93601.publicprofile|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Nursing Times}}</ref> She is an advocate of outcomes measurement in healthcare, something which is novel in mental health.<ref>{{cite web|title=Why outcomes measurement is the key to fixing healthcare|url=http://www.reform.uk/reformer/why-outcomes-measurement-is-the-key-to-fixing-healthcare/|publisher=Reform|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref> She is quoted by the [[NHS Confederation]] as saying: “Measuring care and outcomes in mental health is often put in the ‘too difficult’ box yet capturing data on whether people have homes to live in, jobs to go to, appropriate medication, financial stability and social interactions are possible for other conditions so why not for people with mental health problems too.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dunbar-Rees|first1=Rupert|title=It’s time to take outcomes-based commissioning out of the ‘too difficult’ box, says Dr Rupert Dunbar-Rees|url=http://www.nhsconfed.org/blog/2014/07/take-outcomes-based-commissioning-out-of-the-too-difficult-box|publisher=NHS Confederation|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref> Beacon recommends treatment at home through teams of doctors, nurses and social workers, not through hospital admission.<ref>{{cite news|title=Body and soul|url=https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21613325-professional-schism-hinders-britains-mental-health-system-body-and-soul|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=The Economist|date=23 August 2014}}</ref>
Beacon analysed data supplied by [[Improving Access to Psychological Therapies]] providers in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Have we improved access to mental health services?|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/home/innovation-and-efficiency/have-we-improved-access-to-mental-health-services/5053577.article#.VQYN4_ysVyU|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=4 February 2013}}</ref>
Beacon UK is part of the Forward Thinking Birmingham consortium which has been selected to deliver mental health services across the city of Birmingham from October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘Unique’ consortium wins Birmingham mental health contract|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/hsj-local/acute-trusts/birmingham-childrens-hospital-nhs-foundation-trust/updated-unique-consortium-wins-birmingham-mental-health-contract/5082470.article#.VQX_S_ysVyU|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=18 February 2015}}</ref> The contract agreed with Birmingham South Central [[Clinical Commissioning Group]] requires the consortium to deliver services for children, adolescents and adults under 25 over five years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Private sector-NHS partnership picked for £124m mental health contract|url=http://www.healthinvestor.co.uk/ShowArticle.aspx?ID=3887|accessdate=15 March 2015|publisher=Healthinvestor|date=18 February 2015}}</ref> Community mental health services for children and young people aged 0-25 were criticised by the [[Care Quality Commission]] in its report on children's services in the city in 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Birmingham first children’s trust to be rated ‘outstanding’ |url=https://www.nursingtimes.net/news/reviews-and-reports/birmingham-first-childrens-trust-to-be-rated-outstanding/7015828.article |accessdate=30 October 2018 |publisher=Nursing Times |date=21 February 2017}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Mental health in the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://beaconhs.co.uk/ Beacon website]

{{Primary sources|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox journal | title = British Columbia Medical Journal | cover = [[File:BCMJ 52Vol6 cover.homepage.gif]] | editor = D.R. Richardson | discipline = [[Medicine]] | formernames = Vancouver Medical Association Bulletin, British Columbia Medical Journal | abbreviation = B. C. Med. J. | publisher = [[British Columbia Medical Association|BC Medical Association]] | country = Canada | frequency = 10/year | history = 1924–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.bcmj.org | link1 = http://www.bcmj.org/archive/2010 | link1-name = Online archive | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 01586013 | LCCN = cn 79310920 | CODEN = BCMJAC | ISSN = 0007-0556 | eISSN = }} The '''''British Columbia Medical Journal''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] general [[medical journal]] covering scientific research, review articles, and updates on contemporary clinical practices written by [[British Columbia]]n physicians or focused on topics likely to be of interest to them, such as columns from the BC Centre for Disease Control and the [[Insurance Corporation of British Columbia]]. Although published by the [[Doctors of BC]] professional association, it maintains distance from the association in order to encourage open debate. It hosts an online database of all issues from 2000. The current [[editor-in-chief]] is David R. Richardson.
==Frequency of publication== The journal publishes 10 issues per year, with combined issues in January/February and July/August.
==History== The journal was originally known as the ''Vancouver Medical Association Bulletin''<ref>[http://internatlibs.mcgill.ca/bibliography/titles-q-z.htm McGill University Canadian Health Sciences Periodicals (Q-Z)]</ref> and was published by the Vancouver Medical Association (VMA) for 34 years, from October 1924 until January 1959.
In its early years, the journal relied heavily on advertiser supporting. In 1957, as this income had begun to decline, the VMA and the BCMA entered into an agreement to restructure the publication, including its retitling, with BCMA paying to sustain the financially troubled journal. The first issue under the ''British Columbia Medical Journal'' title was released in January 1959. In January 1963, in response to continued decreasing advertiser support, the BCMA took over the journal completely.
==Cover art== Jerry Wong has been the cover artist for the ''British Columbia Medical Journal'' since 1982.<ref>[http://www.bcmj.org/archive/2000 BCMJ cover archive] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101026042743/http://www.bcmj.org/archive/2000 |date=October 26, 2010 }}</ref>
==Open access== The ''British Columbia Medical Journal'' is an [[open access journal]]. All articles from 2000 onwards are archived on the journal's web site.<ref>[http://www.bcmj.org BCMJ home page]</ref>
==J.H. MacDermot Prize== The ''British Columbia Medical Journal'' welcomes article submissions from student authors, and each year awards a prize of $1000 for the best article written by a medical student in the province of British Columbia. The prize honors [[John Henry MacDermot]] (1883–1969), who became the editor of the ''Vancouver Medical Bulletin'' at its formation in 1924, remaining at the helm until 1967, when he retired.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bcmj.org}}

[[File:Lithuania in Europe (-rivers -mini map).svg|thumb|200px|[[Lithuania]] on the map of [[Europe]]]]
'''Capital punishment in Lithuania''' was ruled unconstitutional and abolished for all crimes in December 1998. [[Lithuania]] is a member of the [[European Union]] and the [[Council of Europe]] and has signed and ratified Protocol 13 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] on complete abolition of death penalty.<ref>[http://www.coe.int/en/web/conventions/full-list/-/conventions/treaty/187/signatures Chart of signatures and ratifications of Treaty 187]</ref> From March 1990 to December 1998, Lithuania executed seven men. The last execution in the country occurred in July 1995, when Lithuanian mafia boss [[Boris Dekanidze]] was put to death.
==Capital punishment in 1990–1998== ===Legal developments and abolition=== In the [[Lithuanian SSR]], the [[criminal code]] provided for death penalty in 16 articles.<ref name=katuo/> After the [[Act of March 11|declaration of independence]] in March 1990, a new criminal code was adopted in December 1991. The death penalty was provided only in Article 105 for premeditated murder in [[Aggravation (law)|aggravating]] circumstances.<ref name=katuo/> Lithuania became a signatory of the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] in February 1992. The covenant, among other things, provided that each person had the right to petition for clemency.<ref name=court/> In July 1994, amendments to the criminal code specified that women or people younger than 18 at the time of the crime could not receive death sentences.<ref name=court/> The execution of death penalty was suspended on July 25, 1996 by a decree of President [[Algirdas Brazauskas]]. The president refused to review clemency petitions without which no death penalty could be carried out.<ref name=court/>
Abolition of death penalty was one of the requirements for Lithuania's membership in the [[European Union]] (see: [[2004 enlargement of the European Union]]), however a poll of public opinion revealed that 70–80% of Lithuanians supported death penalty.<ref name=gelaz/> Thus, members of [[Seimas]] (Lithuanian parliament) were reluctant to vote for the abolition. Instead, Seimas brought a case to the [[Constitutional Court of Lithuania]] to determine whether death penalty was constitutional.<ref name=gelaz/> On December 9, 1998, the Constitutional Court ruled that the death penalty was unconstitutional as it was contrary to Articles 18 (''Human rights and freedoms shall be innate''), 19 (''The right to life of a human being shall be protected by law''), and 21.3 (''It shall be prohibited to torture or injure a human being, degrade his dignity, subject him to cruel treatment, or to establish such punishments'') of the [[Constitution of Lithuania]].<ref name=court/> On December 22, the criminal code was amended to strike out death penalty effective December 31, 1998.<ref name=knisp/> Sentences for nine people on [[death row]] were commuted to life imprisonment.<ref name=coe/>
===List of executions=== Between 1990 and 1995, some 30 people received death sentences.<ref name=katuo/> From March 1990 to December 1998, Lithuania executed seven men by [[Execution by shooting|shooting with a single firearm]]:<ref name=knisp/> # August 8, 1992 – Aleksandras Novatkis (age 24) for murder of a 12-year old witness to his theft # December 12, 1993 – Vladimiras Ivanovas (age 30) for murder of a mother and her 4-year old daughter # December 12, 1993 – Valentinas Laskys (age 40) for murder of four people # January 27, 1994 – Vidmantas Žibaitis (age 29) for murder of three elderly people # September 28, 1994 – Antanas Varnelis (age 23) for six murders and three attempted murders in July–December 1992 # May 18, 1995 – Aleksandras Gudkovas (age 39) for murder of two people # July 12, 1995 – [[Boris Dekanidze]] (age 33) for ordering murder of journalist Vitas Lingys
==Capital punishment in 1918–1940== ===Legal basis and execution methods=== When Lithuania [[Act of Independence of Lithuania|declared independence]] in February 1918, it inherited the 1903 criminal code of the [[Russian Empire]]. The code provided for the death penalty only for crimes against the state (for example, conspiring to intervene with the imperial succession), but military law of war provided for death penalty by shooting or hanging for some 30 different crimes including banditry, robbery, rape, and premeditated murder.<ref name=fuller/> When Lithuania updated its statutes in January and February 1919, the duality remained: the death penalty was abolished in the criminal code but was retained in the military law ({{lang-lt|Ypatingi valstybės apsaugos įstatai|links=no}}).<ref name=draksas/> Article 14 of the military law provided for death penalty for eight crimes, mostly directed against the state, the military, or the officials, but also included armed robbery with murder.<ref name=kuodys31/> The provisional constitution of 1920 even spoke about the abolition of the death penalty.<ref name=draksas/> However, Lithuania with brief interruptions remained under the [[martial law]] until November 1938 when it was lifted due to German pressure in the months before the [[1939 German ultimatum to Lithuania|ultimatum of March 1939]].<ref name=kuodys/>
Historian Sigita Černevičiūtė counted at least 146 executions in interwar Lithuania, though records are incomplete and fragmentary.<ref name=vaise/> Due to the martial law, the executions were carried out by the military by shooting though legal acts provided hanging.<ref name=cerne/> In 1937–1940, Lithuania operated a [[gas chamber]] in [[Aleksotas]] within the First Fort of the [[Kaunas Fortress]].<ref name=cerne/> In January 1937, the criminal code was amended to provide execution by gas which at the time was viewed as more civilized and humane. Lithuania considered and rejected execution by poison.<ref name=cerne/> The first execution was carried on July 27, 1937: Bronius Pogužinskas, age 37, convicted of murder of five members of a Jewish family. Černevičiūtė counted at least nine executions in the gas chamber.<ref name=cerne/> Of the nine, eight were convicted of murder. One, Aleksandras Maurušaitis, was in addition convicted of anti-government actions during the [[1935 Suvalkija farmers' strike]]. The last known execution took place on May 19, 1940 for robbery. The fate of the gas chamber after the [[Occupation of Lithuania by Soviet Union 1940|occupation by the Soviet Union]] in June 1940 is unclear.<ref name=cerne/>
===Noted political executions=== During the chaotic years of the [[Lithuanian Wars of Independence]], not all executions were properly carried out. For example, in 1919, communist activists {{illm|Feliksas Valiukas|lt}} and his wife were executed without a trial and {{illm|Jurgis Smolskis|lt}} was executed (allegedly during an escape attempt) even though he received only a six-year prison sentence.<ref name=kuodys127/>
In February 1920, four men were executed for instigating a mutiny among soldiers stationed in [[Kaunas]].<ref name=luksas1920/> Between the [[1926 Lithuanian coup d'état|coup in December 1926]] and [[Occupation of Lithuania by Soviet Union 1940|Soviet occupation in June 1940]], Lithuania was ruled by authoritarian President [[Antanas Smetona]] and there were several political executions. Four communists were executed in the immediate aftermath of the December 1926 coup while sentences of two others were commuted to life imprisonment.<ref name=cyvas/> Eight people were executed for their participation in the anti-Smetona [[revolt in Tauragė]] in September 1927 while 14 other were pardoned.<ref name=luksas1927/> General {{illm|Konstantinas Kleščinskis|lt}} was convicted of spying for the [[Soviet Union]] and executed in June 1927.<ref name=skuca/> Aleksandras Vosylius was executed in May 1929 for an assassination attempt on Prime Minister [[Augustinas Voldemaras]].<ref name=cyvas/> 18 people received death sentences for their participation in the [[1935 Suvalkija farmers' strike]], but majority received presidential pardons and only five were executed.<ref name=cyvas/> In other instances the presidential pardon was used more generously. For example, three men, including General [[Petras Kubiliūnas]], received pardons for their role in the 1934 anti-Smetona coup and five men received pardons for their conviction of murder during the [[Neumann–Sass case]].<ref name=cyvas/>
==References== {{Reflist|35em|refs= <ref name=cerne>{{cite web |first=Sigita |last=Černevičiūtė |title=Dujų kamera prieškario Lietuvoje 1937-1940 metais |date=April 8, 2014 |url=http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/istorija/duju-kamera-prieskario-lietuvoje-1937-1940-metais-582-418225 |publisher=15 min (republished from ''Naujasis Židinys-Aidai'') |language=lt |accessdate=2016-11-26}}</ref> <ref name=coe>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9CTUR5yOogMC&pg=PA178 |title=The Death Penalty: Abolition in Europe |chapter=Europe: A Death Penalty Free Continent. Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights of the Council of Europe |volume=285 |publisher=Council of Europe |year=1999 |page=178 |isbn=9789287138743}}</ref> <ref name=court>{{cite web| url=http://www.lrkt.lt/lt/teismo-aktai/paieska/135/ta385/content |title=Dėl Baudžiamojo kodekso 105 straipsnio sankcijoje numatytos mirties bausmės |date=1998-12-09 |publisher=Defending Order and Freedom: Constitutional Court of Lithuania |accessdate=2016-11-07 |language=lt}}</ref> <ref name=cyvas>{{cite web |first=Tomas |last=Čyvas |date=2008-05-24 |url=https://cyvas.wordpress.com/2008/05/24/mirties-bausme-nepiktnaudziavusi-diktatura/ |title=Mirties bausme nepiktnaudžiavusi diktatūra |language=lt |publisher=Shortened version published by |first=William C. |last=Fuller Jr |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4un_AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA120 |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=2014 |pages=120–121 |isbn=9781400857722}}</ref> <ref name=gelaz>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9eoyGt-fFmYC&pg=PA400 |title=Constitutional Justice, East and West: Democratic Legitimacy and Constitutional Courts in Post-Communist Europe in a Comparative Perspective |editor-first=Wojciech |editor-last=Sadurski |chapter=The Lithuanian Constitutional Court in its First Decade |first=Nida |last=Gelazis |publisher=Kluwer Law International |year=2002 |isbn=9789041118837 |page=400}}</ref> <ref name=katuo>{{cite book| first=Saulius |last=Katuoka |chapter=The Role of the Lithuanian Centre for Human Rights in Human Rights Protection |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VuVMBU9LulUC&pg=PA137 |page=137 |title=Serious Crime and the Requirement of Respect for Human Rights in European Democracies: Proceedings |volume=918 |publisher=Council of Europe |year=1997 |isbn=9789287132895}}</ref> <ref name=knisp>{{cite web| url=http://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/ivykiai-sukrete-lietuva-mirtininkai.d?id=48206617 |title=„Įvykiai, sukrėtę Lietuvą“. Mirtininkai |first=Egidijus |last=Knispelis |date=2011-08-02 |publisher=[[Delfi.lt]] |accessdate=2016-11-07 |language=lt}}</ref> <ref name=kuodys>{{cite journal |first=Modestas |last=Kuodys | url=http://www.istorijoszurnalas.lt/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=393&Itemid=391 |title=Lietuvos visuomenės reakcija į karo padėties atšaukimą šalyje 1938 m. lapkričio 1 d. |journal=Istorija. Mokslo darbai |language=lt |issn=1392-0456 |year=2011 |volume=83 |page=45}}</ref> <ref name=kuodys31>{{cite thesis |first=Modestas |last=Kuodys |url=http://vddb.library.lt/fedora/get/LT-eLABa-0001:E.02~2009~D_20091204_103200-29846/DS.005.0.01.ETD |title=Karo padėties režimas Lietuvos Respublikoje 1919–1940 m. |language=lt |degree=PhD |year=2009 |publisher=Vytautas Magnus University |page=31}}</ref> <ref name=kuodys127>{{cite thesis |first=Modestas |last=Kuodys |url=http://vddb.library.lt/fedora/get/LT-eLABa-0001:E.02~2009~D_20091204_103200-29846/DS.005.0.01.ETD |title=Karo padėties režimas Lietuvos Respublikoje 1919–1940 m. |language=lt |degree=PhD |year=2009 |publisher=Vytautas Magnus University |pages=127–128}}</ref> <ref name=luksas1927>{{cite web |first=Aras |last=Lukšas |date=2015-12-18 |url=http://lzinios.lt/lzinios/Istorija/aksomine-a-smetonos-diktatura/214576 |title=Aksominė A. Smetonos diktatūra |language=lt |newspaper=Lietuvos žinios |accessdate=2016-11-27 }}</ref> <ref name=luksas1920>{{cite web |first=Aras |last=Lukšas |date=2009-02-20 |url=http://lzinios.lt/lzinios/istorija/1920-ieji-maistas-ar-sukilimas/128053 |title=1920-ieji: maištas ar sukilimas? |language=lt |newspaper=Lietuvos žinios |accessdate=2016-11-27 }}</ref> <ref name=skuca>{{cite web |first=Virginija |last=Skučaitė |date=2005-12-17 |url=http://kauno.diena.lt/dienrastis/kita/isipainiojes-i-sovietu-zvalgybos-tinklus-33652 |title=Įsipainiojęs į sovietų žvalgybos tinklus |newspaper=Kauno diena |language=lt |accessdate=2016-11-27}}</ref> <ref name=vaise>{{cite web| first=Tomas |last=Vaiseta |url=http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/istorija/istorike-sigita-cerneviciute-tarpukariu-dar-nebuvome-pasirenge-naikinti-mirties-bausme-582-487162 |title=Istorikė Sigita Černevičiūtė: „Tarpukariu dar nebuvome pasirengę naikinti mirties bausmę“ |language=lt |accessdate=2016-11-27 |date=2015-02-24 |publisher=15 min}}</ref> }} {{capital punishment}} {{Capital punishment in Europe}}

revision.text:
'''CimaVax-EGF''' is a [[cancer vaccine|vaccine used to treat cancer]], specifically [[non-small-cell lung carcinoma]] (NSCLC). CIMAvax-EGF is composed of [[Recombinant protein|recombinant]] human [[epidermal growth factor|epidermal growth factor (EGF)]] conjugated to a protein carrier.<ref name=Cro2015>{{cite journal|last1=Crombet Ramos|first1=T|last2=Rodríguez|first2=PC|last3=Neninger Vinageras|first3=E|last4=Garcia Verdecia|first4=B|last5=Lage Davila|first5=A|title=CIMAvax EGF (EGF-P64K) vaccine for the treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer.|journal=Expert review of vaccines|date=2015|volume=14|issue=10|pages=1303–11|pmid=26295963|doi=10.1586/14760584.2015.1079488}}</ref>
The vaccine was developed by the [[Center of Molecular Immunology]], [[Havana, Cuba]]<ref>{{cite news |first1=C. |last1=Dillow |date=8 September 2011 |title=Cuba Announces Release of the World's First Lung Cancer Vaccine |url=http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2011-09/cuba-releases-worlds-first-lung-cancer-vaccine |work=[[Popular Science]] |accessdate=2011-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first1=I. |last1=Grillo |date=23 April 2015 |title=Cuba has had a lung cancer vaccine for years |url=http://www.globalpost.com/article/6526566/2015/04/23/cuba-lung-cancer-vaccine-new-york |work=[[GlobalPost]] |accessdate=2014-05-24}}</ref> There are agreements in place to test it in the United States, Japan, and some European countries.<ref name=Patel2013>{{cite news |first1=N. |last1=Patel |date=11 May 2015 |title=Cuba Has a Lung Cancer Vaccine—And America Wants It |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/05/cimavax-roswell-park-cancer-institute/ |work=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |accessdate=2015-05-13}}</ref> It is currently available in Cuba, Colombia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Peru and Paraguay.<ref>{{cite web |first1=H. |last1=Tamayo |date=8 September 2016 |title=Vacuna contra cáncer de pulmón llega al país |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/medellin/vacuna-contra-cancer-de-pulmon-en-colombia/16696285 |work=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)]] |accessdate=2016-09-09}}</ref> In October 2015 [[Serbia]]'s Institute of Virology, Vaccines and Sera (AKA Torlak Institute) signed a memorandum for use in 30 patients as part of a study.<ref name =TorlakInstitute>{{cite web |url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society.php?yyyy=2015&mm=10&dd=21&nav_id=95795 |title='Cuban anti-cancer vaccines soon to be available in Serbia' |date=October 21, 2015}}</ref> CimaVax is relatively cheap to produce and store, and has low toxicity.<ref name=Patel2013 /> Side effects of the vaccine appear to be mild, and include chills, fever, and feeling sick.<ref>{{cite web |date=12 May 2015 |title=Can you tell me about the CimaVax lung cancer vaccine? |url=http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/cancers-in-general/cancer-questions/can-you-tell-me-about-the-cimavax-lung-cancer-vaccine |publisher=[[Cancer Research UK]] |accessdate=2015-07-02}}</ref><ref name=Rodriguez2012 />
== Mechanism == CimaVax is an active [[vaccine]] with which patients are immunized with [[epidermal growth factor]] (EGF), thus raising [[antibodies]] targeting EGF itself. The product is also formulated with the ''[[Neisseria meningitidis]]'' outer protein [[P64k]] and [[Montanide ISA 51]] as [[adjuvant]]s to potentiate the immune response.<ref>Pérez A, et al. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1042/BA20010029/abstract Safety and preliminary immunogenicity of the recombinant outer membrane protein P64k of Neisseria meningitidis in human volunteers]. Biotechnol Appl Biochem. 2001 Oct;34(Pt 2):121-5. PubMed {{PMID|11592918}}.</ref><ref name=Rodriguez2012>{{cite journal |first1=P. C. |last1=Rodríguez |first2=G. |last2=Rodríguez |first3=G. |last3=González |first4=A. |last4=Lage |date=2010 |title=Clinical development and perspectives of CIMAvax EGF, Cuban vaccine for non-small-cell lung cancer therapy |url=http://www.medicc.org/mediccreview/index.php?issue=11&id=128&a=vahtml |journal=[[MEDICC Review]] |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=17–23 |doi= |pmid=20387330}}</ref> The [[epidermal growth factor receptor]] (EGFR) is hijacked by many types of cancer, including cancers of the lung, colon, kidney, and head and neck. By raising antibodies against EGF, which is EGFR's major [[ligand]], the concentrations of EGF in the blood are reduced. Thus CimaVax does not target the cancer cells directly, but is expected to work against these cancers by denying the cancers the growth stimulus they require.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /><ref name=NeningerVinageras2008>{{cite journal |first1=E. |last1=Neninger Vinageras |first2=A. |last2=de la Torre |first3=M. |last3=Osorio Rodríguez |first4=M. |last4=Catalá Ferrer |first5=I. |last5=Bravo |first6=M. |last6=Mendoza del Pino |first7=D. |last7=Abreu Abreu |first8=S. |last8=Acosta Brooks |first9=R. |last9=Rives |first10=C. |last10=del Castillo Carrillo |first11=M. |last11=González Dueñas |first12=C. |last12=Viada |first13=B. |last13=García Verdecia |first14=T. |last14=Crombet Ramos |first15=G. |last15=González Marinello |first16=A. |last16=Lage Dávila |year=2008 |title=Phase II randomized controlled trial of an epidermal growth factor vaccine in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer |url=http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/26/9/1452.long |journal=[[Journal of Clinical Oncology]] |volume=26 |issue=9 |pages=1452–1458 |pmid=18349395 |doi=10.1200/JCO.2007.11.5980}}</ref> For this reason, the Roswell Park group thinks that it may prove most useful as a ''preventive'' vaccine rather than as a cancer therapy ''per se''.<ref name=Patel2013 />
==Research== === Cuba=== Early trials showed a trend towards improved survival among vaccinated test subjects.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /><ref>{{cite journal |first1=P. C. |last1=Rodriguez |first2=E. |last2=Neninger |first3=B. |last3=García |first4=X. |last4=Popa |first5=C. |last5=Viada |first6=P. |last6=Luaces |first7=G. |last7=González |first8=A. |last8=Lage |first9=E. |last9=Montero |first10=T. |last10=Crombet |year=2011 |title=Safety, immunogenicity and preliminary efficacy of multiple-site vaccination with an Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) based cancer vaccine in advanced non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients |url=http://www.jibtherapies.com/content/9/1/7 |journal=[[Journal of Immune Based Therapies and Vaccines]] |volume=9 |issue=7 |pages=7 |doi=10.1186/1476-8518-9-7}}</ref> A direct correlation between the level of antibodies that a vaccinated patient raises against EGF and survival has been observed in several trials,<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /> and in one of the largest trials<ref name=NeningerVinageras2008 /> there was also an age-dependence, with only subjects under the age of 60 benefiting in terms of survival.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /> More antibodies are raised when the vaccine is formulated with Montanide ISA 51 rather than [[aluminum hydroxide]] as an adjuvant, and when patients receive a low dose of [[cyclophosphamide]] three days before vaccine administration.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /> Cyclophosphamide is thought to temporarily block the body's natural [[immune tolerance]] to EGF, thereby increasing antibody titers.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 />
Researchers caution that the early results to date have been in relatively small, early-stage trials with patients that were carefully selected based on predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria, and given specialized oncology care; they may therefore not be representative of most patients who might benefit from the vaccine.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /> It has been urged that CimaVax be tested in patients with earlier-stage NSCLC cancer and in patients who are not candidates for [[chemotherapy]], and that research be conducted to determine which subgroups of NSCLC patients do and don't respond to the vaccine.<ref name=Rodriguez2012 /> It has been suggested that CimaVax may also be effective in other types of cancer that are dependent on EGF/EGFR, including many cases of [[prostate cancer]].<ref name=Rodriguez2012 />
===International === Trials are being organized in the United States, the European Union, Japan,<ref name=Patel2013 /> and Serbia.<ref name =TorlakInstitute/> In late October 2016, the [[United States Food and Drug Administration]] authorized<ref name="Davis2016">{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Henry|title=Roswell Park gets go-ahead to test Cuban lung cancer vaccine|url=http://buffalonews.com/2016/10/26/roswell-park-gets-go-ahead-test-cuban-lung-cancer-vaccine/|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=The Buffalo News|date=26 October 2016}}</ref> the Roswell Park Cancer Institute to conduct a PhaseI/II clinical trial of CimaVAX in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02955290|title=CIMAvax Vaccine and Nivolumab in Treating Patients With Stage IIIB-IV Non-small Cell Lung Cancer - Full Text View - ClinicalTrials.gov|website=clinicaltrials.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref> By the middle of the following month, nearly 200 people had volunteered to be subjects in the trial.<ref name="Hoshaw2016">{{cite news|last1=Hoshaw|first1=Lindsey|title=Cuba Has a Lung Cancer Vaccine; Now U.S. Patients Will Test It|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/futureofyou/2016/11/16/cuba-has-a-lung-cancer-vaccine-now-u-s-patients-will-test-it/|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=KQED News|date=2 December 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cancer vaccines]] [[Category:Health in Cuba]] [[Category:Cuban inventions]]

'''DaVita Clinical Research''', formerly Total Renal Research, Inc., is a [[clinical trial]] company which conducts Phase I and II studies and manages a network of trial sites that operate Phase II-IV clinical trials.<ref>{{cite book|title=Plunkett’s Health Care Industry Almanac 2006|author=Jack W. Plunkett|publisher=Plunkett Research, Ltd.|year=2005}}</ref> It is a wholly owned subsidiary of [[DaVita| DaVita, Inc.]]. It has trial sites in North America and Europe.<ref name=center/> DaVita Clinical Research works with [[contract research organizations|CROs]] and manufacturers on clinical trials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pharmaceuticalcommerce.com/latest-news/davita-highlights-its-full-service-pharmacy-for-renal-disease-patients/|title=DaVita highlights its full-service pharmacy for renal-disease patients|year=2014|publisher=Pharmaceutical Commerce}}</ref>
==History== DaVita Clinical Research was founded in 1985 in a hospital-based facility at [[Hennepin County Medical Center]] in Minneapolis, MN.<ref name=bt/> In 2012, DaVita Clinical Research partnered with [[St. Anthony Hospital (Colorado)|St. Anthony Medical Campus]] to establish a hospital-based research facility containing 80 beds, which increased the company's trial capacity from 42 to 122 beds in North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2012/02/13/davita-to-open-kidney-research-center-at-st-anthony-medical-campus-in-lakewood/|title=DaVita to open kidney research center at St. Anthony medical campus in Lakewood|author=Steve Raabe|year=2012|publisher=Denver Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dddmag.com/news/2012/02/davita-clinical-research-expands-denver|title=DaVita Clinical Research Expands in Denver|year=2012|publisher=DDD Magazine}}</ref>
DaVita Clinical Research merged with HealthCare Partners Clinical Research, which was acquired by [[DaVita|DaVita, Inc.]] in 2012 for $4.4 billion, in December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhealthwatch.com/davita-healthcare-partners-merges-two-if-its-research-organizations-24695/|title=DaVita Healthcare Partners Merges Two if its Research Organizations|author=Michael Essany|year=2014|publisher=mHealthWatch}}</ref><ref name=bt>{{cite web|url=https://www.fiercebiotech.com/r-d/davita-grows-its-house-cro-a-data-centric-merger|title=DaVita grows its in-house CRO with a data-centric merger|author=Damian Garde|year=2014|publisher=FierceBiotech}}</ref>
In August 2016, DaVita Clinical Research announced a global strategic alliance with [[IQVIA|Quintiles]] to optimize end-to-end support for [[Kidney disease|renal disease]] clinical trials.<ref name=center>{{cite web|url=https://www.centerwatch.com/news-online/2016/08/02/quintiles-davita-clinical-research-partner/|title=Quintiles, DaVita Clinical Research partner|year=2016|publisher=CenterWatch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.outsourcing-pharma.com/Article/2016/08/02/Quintiles-and-DaVita-Clinical-Research-announce-strategic-alliance|title=Quintiles and DaVita Clinical Research announce strategic alliance|author=Melissa Fassbender|year=2016|publisher=Outsourcing-Pharma}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:EBSA-Form-700 January 2014.pdf|thumb|300px|EBSA Form 700, version as of January 1, 2014]] [[File:EBSA Form 700 August 2014.pdf|thumb|300px|EBSA Form 700, revised version as of August 2014]] '''EBSA Form 700''' is a form that the United States Government had required certain non-profit organizations to complete and submit, beginning January 1, 2014, in order to claim an exemption from the [[contraceptive mandate]] under the [[Affordable Care Act]]. After the U.S. Supreme court issued temporary injunctions, preventing any penalty against some non-profit institutions who objected to filing the form, the [[U.S. Department of Labor]] issued a new version of the form making it clear that organizations can, instead object by a letter.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/13/us/a-two-page-form-spawns-a-contraceptive-showdown.html</ref>
== Affordable Care Act == In 2010, [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the [[Affordable Care Act]] (ACA), which relies on the [[Health Resources and Services Administration]] (HRSA), part of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), to specify what kinds of preventive care for women should be covered in certain employer-based health plans. HHS exempted churches (including houses of worship, such as synagogues and mosques) and their integrated auxiliaries, associations of churches, and any religious order that engages exclusively in religious activity. Other non-profit organizations that object to any required contraception coverage were to file an EBSA Form 700 with their insurance company notifying them of the non-profit's objection. The insurance company would then provide the contraceptive coverage directly to employees without any involvement of the employer, including any distribution of literature or extra payments by the employer.<ref>{{cite web|title=High court worsens pain of Obamacare birth-control compromise|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-wp-blm-news-bc-health-contraceptives01-20140701,0,3865443.story|accessdate=July 3, 2014}}</ref>
==Litigation== The [[Little Sisters of the Poor]], a Roman Catholic religious order, runs over 25 homes for low-income elderly in the United States<ref>[http://www.littlesistersofthepoor.org/locations/u-s-homes/ Little Sister Directory of Homes] accessed March 27, 2016</ref> and therefore is not automatically exempt from the contraceptive mandate. It objected to filing Form 700 because it believed that doing would make the order complicit in providing contraception, a sin under [[Humanae vitae|Roman Catholic doctrine]]. On December 31, 2013, the day before the filing requirement was to come into effect, Supreme Court Justice [[Sonya Sotomayor]] granted a temporary injunction to the [[Little Sisters of the Poor]], allowing them to simply inform the Secretary of Health and Human Services of their objections, pending resolution of the case.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bazelon|first1=Emily|title=Did Little Sisters of the Poor Win or Lose at the Supreme Court?|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2014/01/little_sisters_of_the_poor_case_supreme_court_grants_a_temporary_reprieve.single.html|accessdate=Jul 6, 2014|work=Slate|date=Jan 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/012414zr_6jgm.pdf Supreme Court order]</ref><ref>[http://www.becketfund.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/13A691-Little-Sisters-v-Sebelius-Order.pdf order from Sotomayor]</ref> Other religious institutions filed similar objections.
On June 30, 2014, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 in ''[[Burwell v. Hobby Lobby]]'' that under the [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act]] (RFRA), closely held for-profit corporations are exempt from the contraceptive mandate, if they object on religious grounds, because the accommodation offered to objecting non-profits would be a less restrictive way to achieve the ACA's interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/13pdf/13-354_olp1.pdf |format=PDF |title=Supreme Court of the United States : Syllabus : BURWELL, SECRETARY OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, ET AL. v. HOBBY LOBBY STORES, INC., ET AL. |publisher=Supremecourt.gov |accessdate=2015-03-11}}</ref>
On July 3, 2014, the Supreme Court granted a temporary exemption to the approach it suggested as a less restrictive alternative in ''Hobby Lobby,'' where the plaintiffs would send an EBSA Form 700 to its insurance issuer, which would pay for the contraception. In an unsigned emergency injunction for [[Wheaton College (Illinois)|Wheaton College]] in Illinois, the court said that instead of notifying its insurance issuer, Wheaton can notify the government. Once notified, the government should notify the issuer. Wheaton believed that by transferring the obligation to cover contraceptives to its insurance issuer, it was triggering that obligation. The emergency injunction does not constitute a ruling on the merits of Wheaton's religious objection. The court said "Nothing in this interim order affects the ability of the applicant’s employees and students to obtain, without cost, the full range of FDA approved contraceptives."<ref>[https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/13pdf/13a1284_ap6c.pdf Order in Pending Case, Wheaton College v. Bruwell, On Application for Injunction], July 3, 2014</ref> In a 15-page dissent joined by the other two women on the court, Justice Sotomayor criticized the majority's reasoning and distinguished it from the situation with the Little Sisters of the Poor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Liptak|first1=Adam|title=Birth Control Order Deepens Divide Among Justices|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/04/us/politics/supreme-court-order-suspends-contraception-rule-for-christian-college.html|accessdate=Jul 3, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=Jul 3, 2014}}</ref>
==Revised form== A revised version of EBSA Form 700, was issued effective August 2014, that says "[a]s an alternative to using this form, an eligible organization may provide notice to the Secretary of Health and Human Services that the eligible organization has a religious objection to providing coverage for all or a subset of contraceptive services...". The form includes a link to a suggested model notification letter. The model notification letter can be found at http://www.dol.gov/ebsa/pdf/modelnoticetosecretaryofhhs.pdf.
==See also== *[[Zubik v. Burwell]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] [[Category:United States government forms]] [[Category:United States Department of Health and Human Services]]

{{manual|date=July 2017}} {{Main|Epilepsy}} '''Epilepsy in animals''' is a group of neurological disorders characterized by [[Epileptic seizure|seizures]], caused by abnormal bursts of electrical activity in the brain. They can start and stop very abruptly and last any amount of time from a few seconds to a few minutes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://cgap.ucdavis.edu/Epilepsy.htm|title=Epilepsy Study|last=Barlough|first=|date=1995|website=|publisher=Ney York: Harper Publishers|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref> Canine epilepsy is often genetic but epilepsy in cats and other pets is rarer, likely because there is no hereditary component to epilepsy in these animals.<ref name=":0" />
== Characteristics == Epilepsy is most commonly recognised by involuntary movements of the head and limbs, however other characteristics include salivation, lack of [[wikt:bodily functions|bodily functions]] and [[anxiety]]. Animals often lose [[consciousness]] and are not aware of their surroundings.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://cvm.ncsu.edu/research/labs/clinical-sciences/companion-animal-epilepsy/|title=Companion Animal Epilepsy|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|publisher=NC State University|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref>
== Handling seizures == Watching an animal have a seizure can be quite frightening. There is not much that can be done during a seizure except to remain calm and not leave the animal alone.<ref name=":1" /> If your pet is having a seizure it is important to make sure they are lying down on the floor away from any water, stairs or other animals. When an animal has a seizure, do not try to grab their tongue or clear their mouth as there is a high chance you will be bitten; contrary to popular myth, neither humans nor animals can "swallow their tongue" during a seizure, so it is safest to stay well away from their mouth during one.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.clevelandclinic.org/2014/06/swallowing-your-tongue-and-other-epilepsy-myths/|title=Swallowing Your Tongue and Other Epilepsy Myths|last=|first=|date=2014|website=Cleveland Clinic Foundation|publisher=|access-date=18 May 2016}}</ref> Timing seizures is also crucial. Take notes of seizures - what time they occur, how often and any other specific information which can be passed onto the vet or emergency animal clinic.<ref name=":1" />
== Dogs == [[File:Potassium_bromide_veterinary.JPG|thumb|200x200px|A bottle of veterinary pharmaceutical potassium bromide oral solution used in dogs, primarily as an [[antiepileptic]] (to stop seizures).]] In [[dog]]s, epilepsy is often an inherited condition. The incidence of epilepsy/seizures in the general dog population is estimated to be between 0.5% and 5.7%.<ref name="Wiersma2">[http://www.k9web.com/dog-faqs/medical/epilepsy.html K9web.com], Wiersma-Aylward, A. 1995. Canine Epilepsy. Retrieved August 6, 2007</ref> In certain breeds, such as the [[Belgian Shepherd]], the incidence may be much higher.
=== Diagnosis === There are three types of epilepsy in dogs: reactive, secondary, and primary.<ref>Peterson, M., "Inherited epilepsy can be devastating in dogs". [http://www.essfta.org/Health_Research/epilepsy.htm essfta.org]</ref> Reactive epileptic seizures are caused by metabolic issues, such as [[Hypoglycemia|low blood sugar]] or [[Renal failure|kidney]] or [[liver failure]]. Epilepsy attributed to [[Canine brain tumors|brain tumor]], [[stroke]] or other trauma is known as secondary or symptomatic epilepsy.
There is no known cause for primary or idiopathic epilepsy, which is only diagnosed by eliminating other possible causes for the seizures. Dogs with [[idiopathic]] epilepsy experience their first seizure between the ages of one and three. However, the age at diagnosis is only one factor in diagnosing canine epilepsy, as one study found cause for seizures in one-third of dogs between the ages of one and three, indicating secondary or reactive rather than primary epilepsy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Podell|first1=M|last2=Fenner|first2=WR|last3=Powers|first3=JD|title=Seizure classification in dogs from a nonreferral-based population|journal=Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association|date=1 June 1995|volume=206|issue=11|pages=1721–8|pmid=7782244}}</ref>
A [[veterinarian]]'s initial work-up for a dog presenting with a history of seizures may include a physical and neurological exam, a [[complete blood count]], [[Blood test|serum chemistry profile]], [[urinalysis]], bile tests, and [[thyroid function tests]].<ref>The Canine Epilepsy Network, [http://www.canine-epilepsy.net/basics/basics_index.html canine-epilepsy.net]</ref> These tests verify seizures and may determine cause for reactive or secondary epilepsy. Veterinarians may also request that dog owners keep a "seizure log" documenting the timing, length, severity, and recovery of each seizure, as well as dietary or environmental changes.
=== Treatment === Many [[antiepileptic]] drugs are used for the management of [[canine epilepsy]]. Oral [[phenobarbital]], in particular, and [[imepitoin]] are considered to be the most effective [[antiepileptic]] drugs and usually used as ‘first line’ treatment.<ref name="Charalambous2">{{cite journal|last1=Charalambous|first1=M|last2=Brodbelt|first2=D|last3=Volk|first3=HA|title=Treatment in canine epilepsy-a systematic review|journal=BMC Veterinary Research|date=22 October 2014|volume=10|pages=257|doi=10.1186/s12917-014-0257-9|pmid=25338624|pmc=4209066}}</ref> Other anti-epileptics such as [[zonisamide]], [[primidone]], [[gabapentin]], [[pregabalin]], [[sodium valproate]], [[felbamate]] and [[topiramate]] may also be effective and used in various combinations.<ref name="Charalambous2" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thomas|first1=WB|title=Idiopathic epilepsy in dogs and cats|journal=The Veterinary clinics of North America. Small animal practice|date=January 2010|volume=40|issue=1|pages=161–79|doi=10.1016/j.cvsm.2009.09.004|pmid=19942062}}</ref> A crucial part of the treatment of pets with epilepsy is owner education to ensure compliance and successful management.<ref>De Risio, L and Platt, S. 2014. Canine and feline epilepsy: diagnosis and management. CAB International: Wallingford, UK. {{ISBN|9781780641096}}.</ref>
== Cats == Seizures in cats have various initiating factors. Cats can have reactive, primary ([[Idiopathy|idiopathic]]) or secondary seizures. Idiopathic seizures are not as common in cats as in dogs however a recent study conducted showed that of 91 feline seizures, 25% were suspected to have had idiopathic epilepsy.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://zimmer-foundation.org/sch/cse.html|title=Feline Seizure Disorders|last=Sonius|first=Chelsea|date=2010|website=|publisher=|access-date=16 May 2016}}</ref> In the same group of 91 cats, 50% were secondary seizures and 20% reactive.<ref name=":2" />
=== Classifications === Idiopathic epilepsy does not have a classification due to the fact there are no known causes of these seizures, however both reactive and symptomatic secondary epilepsy can be placed into classifications.<ref name=":2" />
====Cancer==== [[Meningioma]]s, [[Lymphoma in animals|lymphomas]] and glial cell brain tumours are the most common cancers in cats and are all common causes of seizures.<ref name=":2" />
==== Vascular disease ==== [[Vascular disease]] refers to any condition that effects the flow of blood to the brain and can potentially result in seizure disorders.<ref name=":2" /> Common vascular diseases in cats include, feline ischemic encephalopathy, [[Polycythemia vera|polycythemia]] and [[hypertension]].<ref name=":2" />
==== Inflammatory/infectious ==== Any inflammatory or infectious disease that reaches the brain can result in inducing seizures. The most common inflammatory or infectious diseases which cause seizures in cats include, [[feline infectious peritonitis]], [[Toxoplasmosis]] and [[Cryptococcus]].<ref name=":2" />
==== Reactive seizure disorders ==== Many diseases that occur as a result from illness in parts of the body other than the brain can cause felines to have seizures, especially in older cats. Some of the common [[Metabolism|metabolic]] causes of seizures in felines include, [[hepatic encephalopathy]], [[Kidney|renal]] [[encephalopathy]], [[Idiopathic postprandial syndrome|hypoglycaemia]] and [[hypothyroidism]].<ref name=":2" />
==See also== * [[Canine epileptoid cramping syndrome]] * [[Gerbils#Epilepsy|Epilepsy in gerbils]]
==References== <references/>
{{Seizures and epilepsy}}
