revision.text:
'''Eustress''' means beneficial [[stress (disambiguation)|stress]]—either psychological, physical (e.g. exercise), or biochemical/radiological ([[hormesis]]).
The term was coined by [[endocrinologist]] [[Hans Selye]], consisting of the [[Greek language|Greek]] prefix ''[[eu-]]'' meaning "good", and ''stress'', literally meaning "good stress".{{fact|date=May 2018}}
Eustress was originally explored in a stress model by [[Richard Lazarus]]. It is the positive [[cognitive]] response to [[Stress (psychological)|stress]] that is healthy, or gives one a feeling of fulfilment or other positive feelings.<ref name=Nelson>{{cite book|title=Eustress: An Elusive Construct an Engaging Pursuit|year=2004|publisher=Elsevier Jai|location=Oxford, UK|isbn=0-7623-1057-X|author1=D. L. Nelson |author2=B. L. Simmons |edition=First|editor1=P. L. Perrewé |editor2=D. C. Ganster }}</ref><ref name=Lazarus>{{cite book|last=Lazarus|first=R. S.|title=Psychological Stress and the Coping Process|year=1966|publisher=McGraw-Hill Book Co.|location=New York, Toronto, London}}</ref> Selye created the term as a subgroup of [[Stress (biology)|stress]] to differentiate the wide variety of stressors and manifestations of stress.<ref name= Selye>{{cite book|last=Selye|first=Hans|title=Stress without distress|year=1974|publisher=J.B. Lippincott Company|location=Philadelphia|page=171}}</ref>
Eustress is not defined by the stressor type, but rather how one perceives that stressor (e.g. a negative [[threat]] versus a positive challenge).<ref name=Fevre>{{cite journal|last=Fevre|first=Mark Le|author2=Kolt, Gregory S. |author3=Matheny, Jonathan |title=Eustress, distress and their interpretation in primary and secondary occupational stress management interventions: which way first?|journal=Journal of Managerial Psychology|date=1 January 2006|volume=21|issue=6|pages=547–565|doi=10.1108/02683940610684391}}</ref> Eustress refers to a positive response one has to a stressor, which can depend on one's current feelings of control, desirability, location, and timing of the stressor.<ref name= Fevre /> Potential indicators of eustress may include responding to a stressor with a sense of [[meaning of life|meaning]], [[hope]], or [[Organism|vigor]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nelson|first=Debra|author2=Cooper, Cary|title=Stress and health: A positive direction|journal=Stress and Health|date=1 April 2005|volume=21|issue=2|pages=73–75|doi=10.1002/smi.1053}}</ref> Eustress has also been positively correlated with [[life satisfaction]] and [[well-being]].<ref name = "O'Sullivan">{{cite journal|last=O'Sullivan|first=Geraldine|title=The Relationship Between Hope, Eustress, Self-Efficacy, and Life Satisfaction Among Undergraduates|journal=Social Indicators Research|date=18 July 2010|volume=101|issue=1|pages=155–172|doi=10.1007/s11205-010-9662-z}}</ref> Eustress is uncomfortable, but leads to personal growth.
==Definition== Eustress occurs when the gap between what one has and what one wants is slightly pushed, but not overwhelmed. The goal is not too far out of reach but is still slightly more than one can handle. This fosters challenge and motivation since the goal is in sight. The function of challenge is to motivate a person toward improvement and a goal.<ref name = "Smith 1991">{{Citation|last = Smith|first = Craig|title = Handbook of Social and Clinical Psychology: The Health Perspective|place = New York, NY| publisher = Pergamon Press|year = 1991|chapter = The Self, Appraisal and Coping|pages = 116–137 }}</ref> Challenge is an opportunity-related emotion that allows people to achieve unmet goals.<ref>{{Citation |last1= Smith| first1= C. A. | last2 = Tong| first2= E. M. W. | last3= Ellsworth| first3= P. C. | year= 2014 |title= The Handbook of Positive Emotions | publisher= Guilford| publication-place= New York, NY|pages= 11–27| chapter = The Differentiation of Positive Emotional Experience as Viewed through the Lens of Appraisal Theory| editor-last1= Tugade| editor-first1= M.| editor-last2 = Shiota| editor-first2= M.|editor-last3 = Kirby| editor-first3= L. D.}}</ref> Eustress is indicated by hope and active engagement.<ref name = "HNC">{{cite journal |last=Hargrove |first=M. B. |last2= Nelson|first2=D. L. | last3= Cooper| first3= C. L. |date= 2013 |title= Generating eustress by challenging employees: Helping people savor their work. |journal= Organizational Dynamics|volume=42 |pages= 61–69 |doi=10.1016/j.orgdyn.2012.12.008}}</ref> Eustress has a significantly positive correlation with life satisfaction and hope.<ref name = "O'Sullivan"/> It is typically assumed that experiencing chronic stress, either in the form of distress or eustress, is negative. However, eustress can instead fuel physiological thriving by positively influencing the underlying biological processes implicated in physical recovery and [[Immunity (medical)|immunity]].<ref name = "ACS">{{cite journal |last1= Achor|first1=S. |last2= Crum|first2=A. J. |last3 = Salovey| first3=P.|date= 2013 |title= Rethinking Stress: The Role of Mindsets in Determining the Stress Response |journal= Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume= 104|issue=4 |pages= 716–733 |doi=10.1037/a0031201 |pmid=23437923}}</ref>
==Measurement== Occupational eustress may be measured on subjective levels such as of quality of life or work life, job pressure, psychological coping resources, complaints, overall stress level, and [[mental health]].<ref name=Fevre /> Other subjective methodological practices have included interviews with focus groups asking about stressors and stress level.<ref name=Gibbons>{{cite journal|last=Gibbons|first=Chris|author2=Martin, D. |author3=Moutray, M. |title=Stress and eustress in nursing students|journal=Journal of Advanced Nursing|year=2008|volume=61|issue=3|pages=282–290|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2648.2007.04497.x}}</ref> In one study participants were asked to remember a past stressful event and then answer questionnaires on coping skills, job well-being, and appraisal of the situation (viewing the stressful event as a challenge or a threat).<ref name= McGowan>{{cite journal|last=McGowan|first=Jennifer|author2=Gardner, D. |author3=Fletcher, R. |title=Positive and Negative Affective Outcomes of Occupational Stress|journal=New Zealand Journal of Psychology|date=July 2006|volume=35|issue=2|pages=92–98}}</ref> Common subjective methodologies were incorporated in a holistic stress model created in 2007 to acknowledge the importance of eustress, particularly in the workplace.<ref name= Cohen>{{cite book|title=Handbook of stress, coping, and health : implications for nursing research, theory, and practice|year=2012|publisher=SAGE Publications|location=Thousand Oaks|isbn=9781412999298|page=624|author1=Cohen, J. A. |author2=Tarule, J. M. |author3=Rambur, B. A. |author4=Vallett, C. |edition=2nd|editor=Virginia Hill Rice}}</ref> This model uses hope, positive affect, meaningfulness, and manageability as a measure of eustress, and negative psychological states, negative affect, anxiety, and anger as a measure of distress. Objective measures have also been used and include blood pressure rate, muscle tension, and absenteeism rates.<ref name=Fevre /> Further physiological research has looked for neuroendocrine changes as a result of eustress and distress. Research has shown that [[catecholamines]] change rapidly to pleasurable stimuli.<ref name=Rose>{{cite book|title=Work stress: health care systems in the workplace|year=1987|publisher=Praeger|location=New York|isbn=0275923290|pages=130–147|author=Rose, R. M.|editor1=J. C. Quick |editor2=R. S. Bhagat |editor3=J. E. Dalton |editor4=J. D. Quick }}</ref> Studies have demonstrated that eustress and distress produce different responses in the neuroendocrine system, particularly dependent on the amount of personal control one feels over a stressor.<ref name=Frankenhauser>{{cite book|title=Biobehavioral Bases of Coronary Heart Disease|year=1983|publisher=Plenum Press|location=New York|pages=91–105|author=Frankenhauser, M.|editor1=T. M. Dembroski |editor2=T. H. Schmidt |editor3=G. Blumchen }}</ref>
==Compared with distress== [[File:HebbianYerkesDodson.svg|thumb|350x350px|Yerkes–Dodson curve for a difficult task]] <nowiki> </nowiki>Distress is the most commonly referred to type of stress, having negative implications, whereas eustress is usually related to desirable events in a person's life.<ref name=Selye /> Selye first differentiated the two in an article he wrote in 1975.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Selye |title=Confusion and controversy in the stress field| year=1975| volume = 1| pages=37–44|journal=Journal of Human Stress |doi=10.1080/0097840X.1975.9940406 |issue=2 |pmid=1235113}}</ref> In this article Selye argued that persistent stress that is not resolved through coping or adaptation should be known as distress, and may lead to anxiety, withdrawal, and depressive behavior. In contrast, if stress enhances one's functioning it may be considered eustress. Both can be equally taxing on the body, and are cumulative in nature, depending on a person's way of adapting to the stressor that caused it.<ref name=Nelson /> The body itself cannot physically discern between distress or eustress.<ref>J. Kabat-Zinn. Full catastrophe living - how to cope with stress, pain and illness using mindfulness meditation. (1996)</ref> Differentiation between the two is dependent on one's perception of the stress, but it is believed that the same stressor may cause both eustress and distress.<ref name=Fevre /> One context that this may occur in is societal trauma (e.g. [[the black death]], [[World War II]]) which may cause great distress, but also eustress in the form of [[Psychological resilience|hardiness]], [[Coping (psychology)|coping]], and fostering a sense of [[community]].<ref name=Suedfeld>{{cite journal|last=Suedfeld|first=Peter|title=Reactions to Societal Trauma: Distress and/or Eustress|journal=Political Psychology|date=1 December 1997|volume=18|issue=4|pages=849–861|doi=10.1111/0162-895X.00082}}</ref> The [[Yerkes–Dodson law|Yerkes–Dodson model]] demonstrates the optimum balance of stress with a bell curve (shown in the image in the top right).<ref name= quick>{{cite book|title=Preventative stress management in organizations|year=1997|publisher=American Psychological Association|location=Washington, DC|author1=Quick, J. C. |author2=Quick, J. D. |author3=Nelson, D. L. |author4= Hurrell, J. J. |last-author-amp=yes }}</ref> This model is supported by research demonstrating emotional-coping and behavioral-coping strategies are related to changes in perceived stress level on the Yerkes–Dodson Curve.<ref name=Anderson>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=C. R.|title=Coping behaviors as intervening mechanisms in the inverted-u stress-performance relationship|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|year=1976|volume=61|issue=1|pages=30–34|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.61.1.30}}</ref>
==Occupational== Much of the research on eustress has focused on its presence in the workplace. In the workplace, stress can often be interpreted as a challenge, which generally denotes positive eustress, or as a hindrance, which refers to distress that interferes with one's ability to accomplish a job or task.<ref name=Fevre />
Research has focused on increasing eustress in the workplace, in an effort to promote positive reactions to an inevitably stressful environment.<ref name=Fevre /> Companies are interested in learning more about eustress and its positive effects to increase productivity. Eustress creates a better environment for employees, which makes them perform better and cost less.<ref name = "HNC"/> Occupational stress costs the United States somewhere in between 200 and 300 billion dollars per year.<ref name= Fevre /> If this were eustress instead of distress, these companies would retain this money and the U.S. economy could improve as well. Stress has also been linked to the six leading causes of death: "disease, accidents, cancer, liver disease, lung ailments, suicide."<ref name = "ACS"/> If workers get sick and/or die, there is obviously a cost to the company in sick time and training new employees. It is better to have productive, happy employees. Eustress is necessary for achievement. Eustress is related to well-being and positive attitudes and thus increases work performance.<ref name = "HNC"/>
Techniques such as Stress Management Interventions (SMI) have been employed to increase occupational eustress. SMI's often incorporate exercise, meditation, and relaxation techniques to decrease distress and increase positive perceptions of stress in the workplace.<ref name=Fevre /> Rather than decrease stress in the workplace, SMI techniques attempt to increase eustress with positive reactions to stressful stimuli.<ref name=Fevre />
==Self-efficacy== Eustress is primarily based on perceptions. It is how you perceive your given situation and how you perceive your given task. It is not what is actually happening, but a person's perception of what is happening.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Velez|first1= J. J. |last2= Sorenson|first2= T.|last3 = McKim|first3= A.|last4=Cano|first4=J.|date= 2013|title=Self-efficacy and Task Value Motivation of Students Based on Classroom, Instructor and Student Variables|journal= NCATA Journal |volume= 57|issue= 4|pages=65–70}}</ref> Eustress is thus related to [[self-efficacy]]. Self-efficacy is one's judgment of how they can carry out a required task, action or role.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Howard|first= F.|date=2008 |title= Managing stress or enhancing wellbeing? Positive psychology's contributions to clinical supervision.| journal= Australian Psychologist|volume=43 |issue= 2|pages= 105–113 |doi=10.1080/00050060801978647}}</ref> Some contributing factors are a person's beliefs about the effectiveness about their options for courses of action and their ability to perform those actions.<ref name = "Smith 1991" /> If a person has low self-efficacy, they will see the demand as more distressful than eustressful because the perceived level of what the person has is lower. When a person has high self-efficacy, they can set goals higher and be motivated to achieve them.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ahmed|first1= I.|last2= Qazi|first2=T. F.|last3=Jabeen|first3=S. |date=2011 |title= Self-Efficacy: The Predictor of Educational Performance among University Students.|journal= Information Management and Business Review |volume= 3|issue=2 |pages=57–62}}</ref> The goal then is to increase self-efficacy and skill in order to enable people to increase eustress.
==Flow== When an individual appraises a situation as stressful, they add the label for distress or eustress to the issue at hand. If a situation induces eustress, the person may feel motivated and can experience [[Flow (psychology)|flow]]. Positive psychologist, [[Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi]], created this concept which is described as the moments when one is completely absorbed into an enjoyable activity with no awareness of surroundings.<ref name = "Jackson">{{cite book |last= Jackson |first= S.|date= 2012|title= The Oxford handbook of human motivation|editor-first = R. M.|editor-last=Ryan |location= New York, NY |pages= 127–140|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> Flow is an extremely productive state in which an individual experiences their prime performance. The core elements are absorption, enjoyment and intrinsic motivation.<ref name = "FKS">{{cite journal |last1= Fullagar |first1= C. J. |last2= Knight |first2= P. A.| last3= Sovern|first3=H. S. |date=2013 |title= Challenge/Skill Balance, Flow, and Performance Anxiety |journal= Applied Psychology: An International Review |volume= 62|issue= 2|pages=236–259 |doi=10.1111/j.1464-0597.2012.00494.x}}</ref>
Flow is the "ultimate eustress experience – the [[epitome]] of eustress".<ref name = "HNC"/> Hargrove, Nelson and Cooper described eustress as being focused on a challenge, fully present and exhilarated, which almost exactly mirrors the definition of flow.<ref name = "HNC"/> Flow is considered a peak experience or "the single most joyous, happiest, most blissful moment of your life."<ref name = "Jackson"/>
==Factors== There are several factors that may increase or decrease one's chances of experiencing eustress and, through eustress, experiencing flow. * Stress is also influenced by hereditary predispositions and expectations of society. Thus, a person could already be at a certain advantage or disadvantage toward experiencing eustress.<ref name = "Selye 1983">{{cite book |last= Selye|first=Hans |date=1983 |title=Stress Research Issues for the Eighties |chapter=The Stress Concept: Past, Present and Future|editor-last = Cooper|editor-first=C. L. |location= New York, NY|publisher=John Wiley & Sons |pages=1–20}}</ref> * If a person enjoys experiencing new things and believes they have importance in the world, they are more likely to experience flow.<ref name = "Teng">{{cite journal |last= Teng|first=C. I |date=2011 |title= Who are likely to experience flow? Impact of temperament and character on flow.|journal= Personality and Individual Differences |volume= 50|pages= 863–868|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2011.01.012 }}</ref> * Flow is negatively related to self-directedness, or an extreme sense of autonomy.<ref name = "Teng"/> * Persistence is positively related to flow and closely related to intrinsic motivation.<ref name = "Teng"/> * People with an internal locus of control, have an increased chance of flow because they believe they can increase their skill level to match the challenge.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Kuhnle |first1=C.|last2=Hofer |first2=M. |last3=Killian|first3=B. |date=2012 |title=Self-control as a predictor of school grades, life balance, and flow in adolescents. |journal=British Journal of Educational Psychology |volume= 82 |pages= 533–548 |doi=10.1111/j.2044-8279.2011.02042.x}}</ref> * Perfectionism, however, is negatively related to flow. A person downplays their skill levels therefore making the gap too big, and they perceive the challenge to be too large to experience flow.<ref name = "Jackson"/> On the opposite end of perfectionism, however, there are increased chances of flow. * Active procrastination is positively related to flow. By actively delaying work, the person increases the challenge. Then once the challenge is matched with the person's high skill levels, the person can experience flow. Those who passively procrastinate or do not procrastinate do not have these same experiences. It is only with the purposeful procrastination that a person is able to increase the challenge.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Kim|first=E. |last2= Seo|first2= E. H.|date=2013 |title= The Relationship of Flow and Self-Regulated Learning to Active Procrastination |journal= Social Behavior and Personality|volume=41 |pages= 1099–1114 |doi=10.2224/sbp.2013.41.7.1099}}</ref> * Mindset is a significant factor in determining distress versus eustress. Optimistic people and those with high self-esteem contribute to eustress experiences.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Ambriz |first1= M. G. J.|last2=Izal |first2=M.|last3=Montorio|first3=I. |date=2011|title=Psychological and Social Factors that Promote Positive Adaptation to Stress and Adversity in the Adult Life Cycle|journal= Journal of Happiness Studies |volume= 13 |pages=833–848 |doi=10.1007/s10902-011-9294-2}}</ref> The positive mindset increases the chances of eustress and a positive response to stressors. Currently, the predominant mindset toward stress is that stress is debilitating. However, mindsets toward stress can be changed.
== Examples == [[File:Naisten 400 m aidat.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Engaging in an athletic competition is a common example of eustress.]] Eustress is common in the examples below. {{fact|date=May 2018}}However, the examples depend on how an individual perceives the stress. The examples below are most often perceived as eustress: * Meeting or engaging in a challenge * Desired physical exercise (e. g. [[weight training]], [[running]], [[biking]]) * Playing sports * Watching a suspenseful or scary movie * Riding a roller coaster * Competing in a tournament * Gambling * [[Wim Hof]] breathing
== See also == *[[Distress (medicine)|Distress]], the opposite of eustress. *[[Hans Selye]], who founded the theory of [[stress (biological)|stress]]. *For more general information on stress visit the American Psychological Association's (APA) site [http://www.apa.org/topics/stress/index.aspx here.]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{wiktionary|eustress}} * [http://academic.cuesta.edu/wholehealth/Level2/Lecpages/str04.htm Eustress at Whole Health Stress Management Lecture]
[[Category:Stress]] [[Category:Motivation]] [[Category:Behavioral neuroscience]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2600:1700:6F10:8FB0:7805:204C:EAC4:BFFD|2600:1700:6F10:8FB0:7805:204C:EAC4:BFFD]] ([[User talk:2600:1700:6F10:8FB0:7805:204C:EAC4:BFFD|talk]]) to last revision by JoKony. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Essay-like|date=October 2017}} {{globalize|date=April 2018}} }} {{Feminism sidebar |variants}}
'''Fat feminism''' ('''body-positive feminism)''' is a form of [[feminism]] that merges with the [[fat acceptance movement]]. This form of feminism specifically addresses how [[misogyny]] and [[sexism]] intersect with [[sizeism]] and [[anti-fat bias]]. Body-positive feminists promote acceptance for women of all sizes. Fat feminism originated during [[second-wave feminism]]. Now fat feminists main focus is eliminating perceived bias against fat people. Fat Feminist claim sizeists have negative opinions about people who are overweight such as being lazy, and eating unhealthy foods more often than they should.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/881567968|title=Embody : learning to love your unique body (and quieting that critical voice!)|last=Connie.|first=Sobczak,|date=2014|publisher=Gürze Books|isbn=9780936077819|location=Carlsbad, CA|oclc=881567968}}</ref>
== History ==
===Early years=== Fat feminism and the related [[fat acceptance movement]] originated in the late 1960s, alongside [[second-wave feminism]]. During the late 1960's and 1970's, activists such as Sara Fishman, Dr. Franklin Igway, Judy Freespirit, Aldebaran, and Karen Jones, now known as Karen Stimson, emerged. In 1973, Fishman and Freespirit released ''Fat Liberation Manifesto'' which opposed size discrimination, describing it as sexism. Their movement was met with mixed reactions during the 1960's, the same decade when very thin models, such as Twiggy, became fashionable. Some of the feminists, such as [[Gloria Steinem]] and [[Jane Fonda]], who were active during the decade believed that removing traits of "femaleness" was necessary to gain entrance to a male-dominated society.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fat Feminism: Politics and Perspective |url=http://www.largesse.net/feminism.html |work=Largesse, the Network for Size Esteem |accessdate=21 November 2013 |author=Karen Stimson |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512074722/http://www.largesse.net/feminism.html |archivedate=12 May 2008}}</ref> This ideal would make removing feminie curves, making fat unfeminist. Dispite of this, activists continued to hold demonstrations and continued their course of action. When the fat feminists did not get support from [[National Organization for Women]], they founded organizations to advocate size acceptance, such as Fat Underground (opened up by Judy Freespirit and Aldebaran),<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bitchmedia.org/article/sized-up-fat-feminist-queer-disability|title=Sized Up: Why fat is a queer and feminist issue.|work=Bitch Media|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en}}</ref> The Body Image Task Force (Santa Cruz) and The Body Positive. The first fat feminist book, ''Fat is a Feminist Issue'', by [[Susie Orbach]] was published in 1978.
===1980s–2000=== During the 80's, the movement had mixed success. During this time more organizations and publications against [[size discrimination]] were founded. The first issue of ''Radiance: The Magazine for Large Women'' was published in 1984. Clothing brands and fashion magazines were founded that targeted a plus-size audience. Fat feminists were also suing diet programs for fraudulent claims. However, the popularity of the diet industry did not wane as it was boosted by the fitness boom during the 1980s. By the late 1990s, Americans were spending approximately $40 billion on diet products and programs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eating Disorders: Facts|url=http://www.pbs.org/perfectillusions/eatingdisorders/preventing_facts.html|website=Perfect Illusions|publisher=PBS|accessdate=24 September 2017}}</ref>
In the 1990s fat feminism was gaining steam. For the first time, fat feminism was officially supported by [[National Organization for Women]] when the organization adopted an anti-size discrimination stance with no dissenting vote, and started a body image task force.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wedwick|first1=L.|title=The socialization of a reader: The literary treatment of fatness in adolescent fiction (Unpublished Thesis)|url=https://www.academia.edu/930235/The_socialization_of_a_reader_The_literary_treatment_of_fatness_in_adolescent_fiction|publisher=Illinois Statue University|accessdate=24 September 2017}}</ref> In 1992, Mary Evans Young, a [[size-positive]] activist in England, launched [[International No Diet Day]] (INDD) which was planned as a picnic. Due to the rain, her plan failed, and the celebration was held indoors instead. In 1993 many American feminist groups joined in and 25 states participated in INDD's second annual celebration. [[International No Diet Day]] continues to be observed on May 6 each year.
In 1993, the [[California Supreme Court]] ruled in favor of Toni Cassista who filed a lawsuit against Community Foods, a store in [[Santa Cruz, California]] when she was not hired because of her size. This put an end to work [[weight discrimination|discrimination based on weight]] in the state of California. As of early September 2018, 49 states can fire employees for gaining weight because of at-will employment. A study from Yale University shows that 10% of women and 5% of men experience weight discrimination at work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4883176/weight-discrimination-workplace-laws/|title=49 States Legally Allow Employers to Discriminate Based on Weight|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref>
During the 90s the [[zine]] movement, the [[riot grrrl]] movement, and the [[Fat Liberation]] movement converged for many young activists, resulting in the publication of numerous fat feminist zines. Among these publications were ''Fat!So?: for people who don't apologize for their size'' by [[Marilyn Wann]], ''I'm So Fucking Beautiful'' by [[Nomy Lamm]], and ''Fat Girl: a zine for fat dykes and the women who want them'' produced by The Fat Girl Collective in San Francisco from 1994-1997. In 1996, Toronto-based activist and performance art troupe [[Pretty Porky and Pissed Off|Pretty Porky & Pissed Off (PPPO)]] was founded by [[Allyson Mitchell]], Ruby Rowan, and [[Mariko Tamaki]]. PPPO grew to include other members and worked as a collective until 2005 publishing their zine series, ''Double Double''. [[Nomy Lamm]] was named by ''[[Ms. Magazine]]'' as a "Woman of the Year" in 1997, "For inspiring a new generation of feminists to fight back against fat oppression."<ref>''Ms. Magazine'', January/February 1997</ref> In 1999 [[Marilyn Wann]] expanded her zine into the book ''{{Not a typo|Fat!So?}}: Because You Don't Have to Apologize for Your Size''. In 2005, former ''Fat Girl'' collective members Max Airborne and Cherry Midnight published ''Size Queen: for Queen-Sized Queers and our Loyal Subjects.''
===2000–2010=== The 2000s saw an increase in internet feminism and internet fat activism, {{Citation needed span|text=which have often converged.|date=November 2018|reason=}} The fat acceptance [[blogosphere]] has been dubbed the "fatosphere"<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cooper |first=Charlotte |title=What’s Fat Activism? |url=http://www3.ul.ie/sociology/docstore/workingpapers/wp2008-02.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=University of Limerick Department of Sociology Working Paper Series |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708134627/http://www.ul.ie/sociology/docstore/workingpapers/wp2008-02.pdf |archivedate=8 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and has enjoyed some positive publicity in mainstream publications. Kate Harding and Marianne Kirby, who are prominent fat bloggers, released a co-written self-help book in 2009 called "Lessons from the Fat-o-sphere: Quit Dieting and Declare a Truce with Your Body", which has 27 chapters devoted to different topics, including [[body positivity]], [[health at every size]], and intuitive eating. In 2005, Linda Bacon conceived the [[Health at Every Size]] belief system, which rejects dieting and the weight-based paradigm of health. Bacon's System has been adopted by many fat feminists. Beth Ditto, frontwoman of punk band [[The Gossip]], who is vocal about fat acceptance, attained celebrity in the mid-2000s with the popularity of her band's 2006 album ''[[Standing in the Way of Control]]'', which has raised awareness of the movement.
=== 2010-2017 === Shortly after Barack Obama had started his term as President, the first lady, Michelle Obama, began a campaign called "Let's Move" to draw attention to obesity in America and encourage people to work out, eat healthy and lose weight as a result in 2010.<ref name=":0" />
In May 2015, America met the "Dancing Man." The man, Sean O'Brien, is an over-weight man that loves to dance. A Twitter user posted a picture of him dancing and another photo of him looking upset, captioning the photos with "caught this specimen dancing last week, he stopped when he saw us laughing." Soon after this was posted, Cassandra Fairbanks started a movement to get O'Brien to come to America and dance with the big leagues in Los Angeles where he was celebrated.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/3895459/dancing-man-sean-o-brien-body-shamed-fat-dance-party-los-angeles/|title=Man Fat-Shamed Online Gets VIP Dance Party in L.A.|last=Regan|first=Helen|website=Time|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref>
At the beginning of 2016, Mattel released "Curvy Barbie." This line of Barbie's included dolls that were all shapes, sizes, and a select few of different ethnicities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/604984/mattel-has-finally-released-a-curvy-barbie/|title=Mattel has finally released a "curvy" Barbie|last=Rodriguez|first=Ashley|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref> When asked about the doll the company said "getting rid of Barbie's thigh gap is part of 'evolving the images that come to mind when people talk about barbie."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2018/04/25/tiny-shoulders-rethinking-barbie-hulu-documentary-curvy-doll/540663002/|title=Barbie in 2018 and beyond: How the doll is getting more 'inclusive'|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> The company also says they are "listening to what girls are talking about." <ref name=":1" />
At the beginning of 2017, there was a new trend for fat feminists and body-positive activists to take control of how their fat was seen. The #Don'tHateTheShake videos posted all over social media, were about both fat men and women stripping down to their undergarments and dancing to upbeat music as if they were at a dance club. This was created by Melissa Gibson, but has gained traction because of Megan Jayne Crabbe, who spreads body positivity all over social media to her large follower count. Crabbe has recently published a book about body positivity, that has yet to be published in the United States, called ''Body Positive Power''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/anorexia-survivor-body-positive-blogger-megan-jayne-crabbe-body-posi-panda-instagram-followers-love-a7567731.html|title=The blogger sharing before and after pics with a twist|date=2017-02-07|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>''.''
==Intersections with Other Forms of Feminism== Many of the authors in ''Shadow on a Tightrope: Writings By Women on Fat Oppression'' are lesbians, and many were involved in [[lesbian feminism]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Bodies out of Bounds: Fatness and Transgression |pages=137–138 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kxvlP_3AH40C&pg=PA138&dq=fat+feminism&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Q-97UZeYO4HbPcCCgOgK&ved=0CC8Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=fat%20feminism&f=false |year=2001 |publisher=University of California Press |authors=Jana Evans Braziel, Kathleen LeBesco }}</ref> Their experience of fatness is different from that of straight fat women{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} because of their experience of combined discrimination based on their sex, size and sexual orientation.
Fat women of color have a different experience than fat white women because of their intersectional experiences of not only size discrimination and misogyny, but racism as well.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Clinical Implications of Body Image Among Rural African-American Women |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1525-1497.2000.06479.x/full |authors=Baturka, N.; Hornsby, P. P.; Schorling, J. B. |date=18 May 2004 |accessdate=21 November 2013 |publisher=Journal of General Internal Medicine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121062234/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1525-1497.2000.06479.x/full |archivedate=21 November 2013 |deadurl=no |doi=10.1111/j.1525-1497.2000.06479.x|pmc=1495436 }}</ref> Women of color also need to be represented in the media. People of color in general, overweight or not, are portrayed negatively in television shows, movies, and even major news channels.<ref>Carter, Tyler J.. The University of Mississippi, ProQuest Dissertations Publishing, 2015. 1601156.</ref> Some examples of women of color in the media is bell hooks, Lauryn Hill, Sonya Renee Taylor, and Gabourey Sidibe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://newyork.endangeredbodies.org/eight_body_positive_women_of_color_who_have_inspired_my_body_love_journey|title=Eight Body Positive Women of Color Who Have Inspired My Body Love Journey|work=New York|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en}}</ref>
==Fat Feminism and Women of Color== {{Original research section|date=May 2018}}
Women of color experience fatness and the body positivity movement different from white women due to their experiences with racial oppression on top of anti-fat bias. According to A.A. Williams, women of color often do not view being fat as being synonymous with being unattractive.<ref>Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 1-16, 5.</ref> They further opine that fat women of color use their weight and personal style as a way to counter dominant beauty standards that have historically been defined by whiteness.<ref name="Williams, A.A 2017">Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 1-16, 6.</ref> Personal styles include having natural hair or dreads for black women as well as embracing larger and curvier figures.<ref name="Williams, A.A 2017" /> Research suggests that women of color, as well as communities of color in general, may consider more body types as beautiful than white beauty standards.<ref name="Williams, A.A 2017" /> However, because women of color are often excluded from fat positivity and acceptance movements, many have turned to social media as a way of finding inclusion within the fat feminist movement.<ref name="Williams, A.A 2017" /> Fat women of color resist dominant beauty standards by creating intersectional frameworks for accepting fat women of all identities.<ref>Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 1-16, 7.</ref> Fat women of color also work to resist fetishization by the male gaze or by those giving unwanted health advice while also creating positive and accepting spaces for themselves.<ref>Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 1-16, 12.</ref><ref>Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 1-16, 6, 15.</ref>
When talking about the Fat Feminist movement Women of Color are often overlooked and included less because of white privilege. According to the article Fat People of Color, studies show that "14% of the 1018 roles on prime-time television programming portrayed 'overweight' or 'obese' females" and even less are overweight women of color.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Apryl|last2=Williams|first2=Apryl A.|date=2017-02-14|title=Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online|url=https://www.mdpi.com/2076-0760/6/1/15|journal=Social Sciences|language=en|volume=6|issue=1|pages=15|doi=10.3390/socsci6010015}}</ref> When these women are portrayed in social media it is often that they are over sexualized even for a young age.<ref name=":2" />
== Theories that can be Associated with fat feminism == {{Original research section|date=July 2018}} A theory presented by Michel Foucault in his book ''The Perverse Implantation'' suggests that society plants ideas inside the minds of individuals all over the world which creates industries and in turn controls the people and the way their belief system works.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://yoonbinmin.wordpress.com/2013/10/22/the-perverse-implantation-by-foucault/|title="The Perverse Implantation" by Foucault|date=2013-10-22|work=yoonbinmin|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref> This is much like the dieting industry, built to help people overweight become "normal" which in a society such as this, the goal is to be ''thin'' or ''curvy'', not fat.{{synthesis-inline|date=July 2018}} ''Weight Watchers'', ''Nutrisystem'', ''DetoxTea'', surgical weight loss options, are all tailored towards individuals to lose weight. These are ideas fat feminists and body-positive activists are completely against. Laura S. Brown, author of Fat Oppression and Psychotherapy, examines that being fat isn't unhealthy.<ref name=":3" /> The standards that we hold over-weight individuals to, is what's unhealthy for these individuals. Bulimia, anorexia, depression, anxiety, etc., are all brought on because of the standards that society has over those who are considered outsiders to what's normal.<ref name=":3">Brown, Laura (1989). ''Fat Oppression and Psychotherapy''. The Haworth Press. pp. 20–23. {{ISBN|0-86656-954-5}}.</ref>
==How Fat Ties to Feminism== {{Original research section|date=May 2018}}
There are many reasons why people{{Who|date=November 2018}} consider fat to be a feminist issue. First, "several US health and women's studies scholars have declared obesity a feminist issue on the grounds that women, specifically African American and poor women, are more likely than men to be obese."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com.libproxy.nau.edu/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=128acb23-767f-4eb7-a664-9e5aa42e061a@sessionmgr104|title=Login - CAS – Central Authentication Service|website=eds.b.ebscohost.com.libproxy.nau.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> The marginalization women feel simply due to their gender can affect their eating habits in a negative way. Second, the intersection of obesity with race and [[socioeconomic status]] represents concerns in regards to environmental policy issues. Relating to this second reason is the idea that women, particularly women of color, are generally more likely to be obese than men because of things such as child rearing and a lack of access to fresh produce and goods. In addition, the mere idea of becoming fat has caused many women to develop an [[eating disorder]] that is sometimes detrimental or life altering. Moreover, women may over eat in an attempt to avoid being an object of the [[male gaze]] by making them more invisible to men's desires. Lastly, the intersectionality of being fat and being a woman is at the heart of fat feminism because discrimination and prejudice often occur as a result of gender and body type. The points above that connect fatness to feminism revolve around the varying experiences that body type can produce when combined with socioeconomic status, race, gender, [[sexual orientation]], and many other identities. <ref>Saguy, Abigail C. "Why Fat is a Feminist Issue", University of California, Los Angeles, 2012. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/257663670_Why_Fat_is_a_Feminist_Issue</ref>
== Problems with Fat Feminism == While Fat Feminism has made positive changes in the world, it is not perfect. Within Fat Studies there is a sort of privilege for the curvy girl, and a disadvantage for the thin girl. This is called the anti-thin bias and can close up this form of feminism to a girl because of her body type.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nash|first=Meredith|last2=Warin|first2=Megan|date=2016-09-16|title=Squeezed between identity politics and intersectionality: A critique of ‘thin privilege’ in Fat Studies|url=http://journals.sagepub.com.libproxy.nau.edu/doi/full/10.1177/1464700116666253|journal=Feminist Theory|language=en|volume=18|issue=1|pages=69–87|doi=10.1177/1464700116666253|issn=1464-7001}}</ref> This type of feminism also is very closed off to anyone who is not a white curvy girl. Overweight men and Overweight Women of Color are often excluded from this movement. The article Feminism and the Invisible Fat Man discusses how fashion tends and body fashions may seem to effect women more, but men are just as effected.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Kirsten|last2=McNaughton|first2=Darlene|date=March 2007|title=Feminism and the Invisible Fat Man|url=http://journals.sagepub.com.libproxy.nau.edu/doi/pdf/10.1177/1357034X07074780|journal=Body & Society|language=en|volume=13|issue=1|pages=107–131|doi=10.1177/1357034x07074780|issn=1357-034X}}</ref> Women of Color experience the same kind of invisibility, they are not represented nearly as well as white women within this movement.<ref name=":2" /> == See also == {{Portal|Feminism}} * [[Body image]] * [[Fat acceptance movement]] * [[International No Diet Day]] * [[International Size Acceptance Association]] * [[Marilyn Wann]] * [[Nomy Lamm]] * [[Self-image]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Bibliography == * Malson, Helen and Burns, Maree, eds. ''Critical Feminist Approaches to Eating Dis/Orders'', Routledge, 2009. * Murray, Samantha. ''The 'Fat' Female Body'', Palgrave Macmillan, 2008. * [[Susie Orbach|Orbach, Susan]]. ''Fat Is a Feminist Issue'', Arrow Books; New edition, 2006. * Bordo, Susan. ''Unbearable Weight: Feminism, Western Culture, and the Body, Tenth Anniversary Edition'', University of California Press, 2004. * Braziel, Jana Evans and LeBesco, Kathleen. ''Bodies out of Bounds: Fatness and Transgression'', University of California Press, 2001. * Manton, Catherine. ''Fed Up: Women and Food in America'', Praeger, 1999. * Malson, Hellen. ''The Thin Woman: Feminism, Post-structuralism and the Social Psychology of Anorexia Nervosa (Women and Psychology)'', Routledge, 1997. * Cole, Ellen and Rothblum, Esther D. and Thone, Ruth R. ''Fat: A Fate Worse Than Death? : Women, Weight, and Appearance (Haworth Innovations in Feminist Studies)'', Routledge, 1997. * Hirschmann, Jane R. ''When Women Stop Hating Their Bodies: Freeing Yourself from Food and Weight Obsession'', Ballantine Books, 1996. * Fallon, Patricia and Katzman, Melanie A. and Wooley, Susan C., eds. ''Feminist Perspectives on Eating Disorders'', The Guilford Press, 1996. * MacSween, Morag. ''Anorexic Bodies: A Feminist and Sociological Perspective on Anorexia Nervosa'', Routledge, 1995. * Rothblum, Esther D. and Brown, Laura. ''Fat Oppression and Psychotherapy: A Feminist Perspective'', Routledge, 1990. * Parker, Patricia A. ''Literary Fat Ladies: Rhetoric, Gender, Property'', Methuen, 1988. * Harding, Kate and Kirby, Marianne. ''Lessons from the Fat-o-sphere: Quit Dieting and Declare a Truce with Your Body'', 2009. * Various. ''Shadow on a Tightrope: Writings by Women on Fat Oppression'', Aunt Lute Books, 1995. * Frater, Lara. ''Fat Chicks Rule!: How To Survive in a Thin-Centric World'', Gamble Guides, 2005. * Farrell Erdman, Amy. ''Fat Shame: Stigma and the Fat Body in American Culture'', 2011. * Shaw Elizabeth, Andrea. ''The Embodiment of Disobedience: Fat Black Women's Unruly Political Bodies'', Lexington Books, 2006. * Kinzel, Lesley. ''Two Whole Cakes: How to Stop Dieting and Learn to Love Your Body'', The Feminist Press, 2012. * Goodman, Charisse. ''The Invisible Woman: Confronting Weight Prejudice in America'' * Williams, A.A. Fat People of Color: Emergent Intersectional Discourse Online. Soc. Sci. 2017, 6, 15. http://www.mdpi.com/2076-0760/6/1/15

Stimson] * [http://www.fwhc.org/health/fatfem.htm Fat and Feminist Large Women's Health Experiences] * [http://womenst.library.wisc.edu/fc/fcwebsizeacc.htm The Web of Size Acceptance: Internet Resources for Exploring a Feminist Issue] * [http://loveyourbody.nowfoundation.org/ Love Your Body] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060813203652/http://naafa.org/info/legal/court.html Recent Lawsuits about Fat Discrimination] * [[Laurie Toby Edison|Laurie Toby Edison's]] & Debbie Notkin's body image blog ''[http://laurietobyedison.com/discuss/ Body Impolitic]''

page.title: Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity Sponsored Ministries

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2013}} The '''Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity (FSCC) Sponsored Ministries''' (formerly FSCC HealthCare Ministry) is a not-for-profit system of health care facilities and a liberal arts college headquartered in [[Manitowoc, Wisconsin]]. The system has hospitals and long-term care facilities in Nebraska, Ohio and Wisconsin, and Silver Lake College of the Holy Family in Manitowoc. FSCC Sponsored Ministries is dedicated to carrying out its sponsor's (the [[Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity]]) commitment to the healing and education ministries of the [[Catholic Church]]. == Mission ==
The mission of the Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity Sponsored Ministries is to carry out the commitment of the Sponsor to the healing and educational mission of the Catholic Church through the provision of quality health care and educational services. In a spirit of partnership with dedicated religious and lay leaders, the Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity Sponsored Ministries will strengthen the Sponsor's commitment by managing change, ensuring stewardship of resources and integrating mission and values.from http://www.fsccm.org/health-care-ministry.asp
== Ministries == *[http://www.hfmhealth.org/ '''Holy Family Memorial'''], [[Manitowoc, Wisconsin]]. *[http://www.genesishcs.org/ '''Genesis HealthCare System'''], [[Zanesville, Ohio]]. *[http://www.fcswp.org/ '''Franciscan Care Services'''], [[West Point, Nebraska]]. *[http://www.stpaulelders.org/ '''St. Paul Elder Services'''], [[Kaukauna, Wisconsin]]. *[https://www.sl.edu/ '''Silver Lake College of the Holy Family'''], [[Manitowoc, Wisconsin]]. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.fsccm.org/index.asp}} * [http://www.fscc-calledtobe.org/ Franciscan Sisters of Christian Charity] * [http://www.chausa.org/ Catholic Health Association of the U.S.] * [http://www.catholichealthcare.us/ Catholic health care in the U.S.] [[Category:Catholic health care]] [[Category:Manitowoc County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Franciscan spirituality]]

The '''[[HIV/AIDS]] epidemic in Ukraine''' is one of the fastest growing in the world.<ref name=KP301112/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/media_20869.html|title=HIV/AIDS menaces progress in Ukraine|publisher=[[UNICEF]]|date=11 May 2004|accessdate=30 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2006/10/23/ukraine-end-human-rights-abuses-fueling-hivaids|title=Ukraine: End Human Rights Abuses Fueling HIV/AIDS|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=23 October 2006|accessdate=30 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/elton-john-gives-aids-charity-concert-in-ukraine-453593.html|title=Elton John gives AIDS charity concert in Ukraine|work=[[The Independent]]|date=18 June 2007|accessdate=30 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/ECAEXT/0,,contentMDK:20657882~pagePK:146736~piPK:146830~theSitePK:258599,00.html|title=Ukraine Launches Information Campaign Against AIDS|publisher=[[World Bank]]|date=27 September 2005|accessdate=30 January 2009}}</ref><ref name=KyivPost1>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/28938/|title=Ukraine losing HIV/AIDS fight|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=7 May 2008|accessdate=2 December 2008}}</ref> Ukraine has one of the highest rates of increase of HIV/AIDS cases in [[Eastern Europe]]<ref name="kids">{{cite news|url=http://un.ua/eng/article/166144.html |title=United Nations Registers More Children With AIDS In Ukraine |agency=[[Ukrainian News Agency]] |date=1 December 2008 |accessdate=2 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229131839/http://un.ua/eng/article/166144.html |archivedate=February 29, 2012 }}</ref> and highest HIV prevalence outside Africa.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kerrigan |first=Deanna |authorlink= |date= 2013 |title= The Global HIV Epidemics among Sex Workers |pages= 134 |chapter= Ukraine |isbn= 978-1-4648-0388-8}}</ref> Experts estimated in August 2010 that 1.3 percent of the adult population of Ukraine was infected with [[HIV]], the highest in all of [[Europe]].<ref name=KyivPAug102010>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/hiv-infection-rate-lack-of-spending-worry-ukraine--77668.html|title=HIV infection rate, lack of spending worry Ukraine public health professionals|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=10 August 2010|accessdate=10 August 2010}}</ref><ref name=WADUkraine2011/> Late 2011 Ukraine numbered 360,000 HIV-positive persons (increase in the rate close to zero compared with 2010).<ref name=WADUkraine2011>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/117980 On World AIDS Day, a dose of good news], [[Kyiv Post]] (1 December 2011)</ref> Between 1987 and late 2012 27,800 Ukrainians died of AIDS.<ref name=KP301112/> In 2012 tests revealed 57 new cases of HIV positive Ukrainians each day and 11 daily AIDS-related deaths (on a population of roughly 45 million at the time).<ref name=KP301112/><ref name=CIAFBUKR2012>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/up.html Ukraine], [[CIA Factbook]] (page last updated on November 14, 2012)</ref>
Identified in the country in 1987,<ref name=KP301112/> HIV/AIDS appeared to be confined to a small population until the mid-1990s, when a sudden and explosive [[epidemic]] emerged among injecting [[Narcotic|drug]] users and prostitutes against the background of severe economic crisis and collapse of social healthcare system.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/190751460|title=HIV/AIDS : global frontiers in prevention/intervention|date=2009|publisher=Routledge|others=Pope, Cynthia., White, Renée T., Malow, Robert.|isbn=9780415953825|location=New York|oclc=190751460}}</ref> Between 2005 and 2012 seven regions south and southeastern Ukraine contributed 61.8% of cases but only 32.3% of the population.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vitek|first=Charles R.|last2=Čakalo|first2=Jurja-Ivana|last3=Kruglov|first3=Yuri V.|last4=Dumchev|first4=Konstantin V.|last5=Salyuk|first5=Tetyana O.|last6=Božičević|first6=Ivana|last7=Baughman|first7=Andrew L.|last8=Spindler|first8=Hilary H.|last9=Martsynovska|first9=Violetta A.|date=2014-09-24|title=Slowing of the HIV Epidemic in Ukraine: Evidence from Case Reporting and Key Population Surveys, 2005–2012|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4174506/|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=9|issue=9|pages=e103657|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0103657|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4174506|pmid=25251080}}</ref> According to data reported in 2015 the epidemic is still on the rise, but it doesn't limit itself by a small group of drug users and appears to be accelerated within all parts of Ukrainian population with growing numbers of infected women.<ref name=Platt>{{cite book |last=Platt |first=Lucy |authorlink= |date=2015 |title= HIV Epidemics in the European Region: Vulnerability and Response |pages=35–36|chapter= Case Study: United Kingdom and Ukraine |isbn= 978-1-4648-0388-8}}</ref>
==Situation==
===Spread of AIDS=== HIV officially reached the territory of the former Soviet Union in 1987,<ref name=KP301112/> about 5 years after the virus itself was discovered. Until 1995 there were only a few known cases of HIV infections in Ukraine. The country was therefore deemed to be “low risk” by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in terms of spread at that time.<ref name="Burruano und Seydel">''L. Burruano und J. Seydel'' Die Ausbreitung von HIV/AIDS in der Ukraine. Gesundheitswesen 2006;68, 8-9, 571-574, Georg Thieme Verlag, Stuttgart. ISSN 0941-3790</ref> Between 1987 and 1994, 183 infections were reported.<ref name=bookSTD>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qe5Edc5EYJEC&pg=PA49 |title=Sexually Transmitted Diseases|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill Professional]]|edition=4th|year=2007|isbn=978-0071417488}}</ref>
In the mid-1990s, the transmission was primarily through injecting drug use.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} By 2001, however, the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use had declined to 57% from 84% in 1997.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} During that time, [[Heterosexuality|heterosexual]] transmission increased from 11% to 27%, and [[perinatal]] transmission increased from 2% to 13% as a proportion of total cases.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} [[File:Registered HIV prevalence in Ukraine.jpg|thumb|400px|Registered [[HIV]] [[prevalence]] in Ukraine (late 2007)]] [[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]] estimates that the number of people infected with HIV/AIDS in 2003 was 360,000 (range 180,000 to 590,000), representing an adult prevalence of 1.4%. According to the Ministry of Health—which estimates that by 2002 there were more than 500,000 people infected or nearly 2% of the adult population—the epidemic has now spread to every [[Administrative divisions of Ukraine|oblast]] in the country. Prevalence in the southern and eastern oblasts ([[Odessa Oblast|Odessa]], [[Mykolaiv Oblast|Mykolaiv]], [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast|Dnipropetrovsk]], and [[Donetsk Oblast|Donetsk]]) is about three times higher than rates in the rest of the country.<ref name=usaid/> A major reason for this is the fact that the urbanized and industrialized regions in the East and South of Ukraine suffered most from the economic crisis in the 90s, which in turn led to the spread of unemployment, alcoholism, and drug abuse, thus setting the conditions for wider spread of the epidemic.<ref name=undr>[http://europeandcis.undp.org/rhdr.aids2008/report/hiv_ukraine_en.pdf Vulnerability Assessment of People Living With HIV (PLHIV) in Ukraine] ''[[United Nations Development Programme]], page 24'' - Retrieved on 8 December 2009.</ref>
From 1995 to 2007, the primary means of HIV transmission was through injection drug use, but by 2008, sexual contact outpaced injection drug use as the primary form of transmission.<ref name=usaid/> By 2009, almost 44 percent of new infections occurred through sexual transmission, and 36 percent were through injecting drug use (according to [[USAID]]; according to [[Center for Strategic and International Studies|CSIS]] in 2009 the proportion of new cases of HIV/AIDS attributable to injecting drug use was 60%).<ref name=CSISMarch2012>[http://csis.org/publication/injection-drug-use-ukraine Injecting Drug Use in Ukraine], [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] (March 2012)</ref>).<ref name=usaid/>
In 2007 about 0.96 percent of [[Ukrainians]], or about 440,000 citizens, were estimated to be living with HIV/AIDS,<ref>http://www.unaids.org/en/KnowledgeCentre/HIVData/mapping_progress.asp {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831103339/http://www.unaids.org/en/KnowledgeCentre/HIVData/mapping_progress.asp |date=August 31, 2009 }}</ref> down from 1.46 percent of the population in 2005, or 685,600 citizens, according to UNAIDS.<ref name=KyivPost1/> The number of HIV/AIDS cases in Ukraine reduced by 200 or 3.9% to 4,900 in the period of January–November 2008, compared with the corresponding period of last year.In 2007 the majority of those infected where under 30 years of age; with a full 25% of those affected still in their teens.<ref name=UNYouth2007>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iCBr_yDbqBYC&pg=PA185 |title=World Youth Report 2007:Young People's Transition to Adulthood|publisher=[[United Nations]]|page=185|isbn=978-92-1-130257-8|year=2007}}</ref>
Although HIV/AIDS had remained concentrated among marginalized and vulnerable populations, it was feared in 2008 it may be spreading to the general population.<ref name="undr"/> According to the Ministry of Health, Ukraine has already surpassed the “optimistic” projections of an HIV/AIDS rate of 2% in 2010.<ref name=usaid>[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:HvprziBdLogJ:transition.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/aids/Countries/eande/ukraine_profile.pdf+USAID+Health+Profile+Ukraine+-+November+2010&hl=nl&gl=nl&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjbApo5ati5o-ZAZpYeeOYqoyU1GMEz_sM9v3u9HkvHRCe48IxeYOloIQW-OVcOZNNgskcHHQKc_yK0zDEpMDmejPkW7Lxdobvcz7Y04-gnv9VplsdMRAe7XOnFRG5JOVO00Gje&sig=AHIEtbSDRq-EcaDnIEfeV8FN56LqTPDPIg "Health Profile: Ukraine"]. [[United States Agency for International Development]] (December 2004). Retrieved 7 September 2008. {{PD-notice}}</ref>
According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV infection rate fell by 6.7% and mortality from AIDS was down by 7.9% in 2014. <ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (3 December 2014)</ref> HIV travel restrictions: [[WWW.PLWHA.ORG|WWW.PLHIV.ORG]]
===Prisons=== {{see also|Prisons in Ukraine}} Between 1996 and 2001 about 26 percent in various prisons across Ukraine tested HIV- positive. In a January 2005 study between 15 and 30 percent of prisoners tested HIV- positive.<ref name=hepcrate/>
Early 2005 rates of up to 95 percent of the prisoners were found [[Hepatitis C]] positive.<ref name=hepcrate>[http://www.aidslex.org/site_documents/PR-0001E.pdf HIV/AIDS and hepatitis C in prisons: the facts], [[AIDSLEX]] (2006) Retrieved 1 April 2010.</ref>
Early 2010 there were over 147,000 people held at [[prisons in Ukraine|prisons]] and more than 38,000 at pre-trial detention facilities in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|title=Number of inmates in Ukraine rises for first time in 7 years|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=1 April 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131231948/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62887/|archivedate=31 January 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Spread of AIDS among children=== The number of children with AIDS in Ukraine is on the rise since the number of mothers with HIV grows by 20-30% annually. According to the United Nations, the number of pregnant women with HIV was 0.34% in 2007, which was the highest index in Europe. According to the United Nations, of nearly 18,000 children born by HIV-positive mothers in Ukraine, 10,200 children have not contracted HIV and another 5,500 children under eighteen months have yet to receive final results of an examination. In Ukraine, 1,877 children have been confirmed as HIV positive and 244 have died of AIDS. The United Nations notes that the program of preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Ukraine has cut the share of such transmission from 27% of the number of HIV cases in 2000 to 7% in 2006.<ref name=kids/> According to the [[Health Ministry of Ukraine]] the HIV transmission from mother to a child was 4.28% in 2014 compared to 29% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237701.html|title=Number of HIV infection cases in Ukraine down by almost 7% since early 2014, says health ministry|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref>
==Preventive measures== From 2001 till June 2015 HIV-positive Ukrainian citizens were barred from travelling abroad and HIV-positive foreigners were forbidden to enter Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|title=Ukraine lifts ban on HIV-positive visitors|agency=[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150823140043/http://www.unian.info/society/1108648-ukraine-lifts-ban-on-hiv-positive-visitors.html|archivedate=23 August 2015|df=}}</ref>
===Harm reduction programs=== [[Image:An ambulance in Kiev.jpg|right|thumb|An ambulance in [[Kiev]]]] Since 2003, drug substitution programs have been introduced in Ukraine. By the end of September 2008, they were offered to about 2200 persons in 38 locations.<ref name="Alliance">{{cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|title=''Alliance''. International HIV and AIDS Alliance, Kiew|accessdate=1 December 2012|archivedate=6 September 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906023039/http://www.aidsalliance.org/sw54545.asp|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> Mostly Buprenorphine (Trademark ‘Subutex‘) is dispensed, which is significantly more expensive than Methadon. It is also less frequently used and thoroughly researched worldwide. Buprenophin is more accepted by society and politicians, however, because it is seen as a painkiller. Methadone, in contrast, is viewed as a drug subscribed at public expense.<ref name="Weber">''C. Weber'' Assessment 2007 in Donetsk. http://www.aids-ukraine.org.</ref>
In 2012 patients and advocacy groups complained of occasional supply shortages in Ukrainian AIDS clinics.<ref name=KP301112>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hiv-prevention-aids-treatment-still-lags-in-ukraine-316990.html|title=HIV prevention, AIDS treatment still lag in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=30 November 2012|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=AP29612/> In June 2012 advocacy groups accused [[Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)|Health Ministry]] officials of [[Corruption in Ukraine#Corruption in healthcare|embezzling money]] that should be used to treat [[AIDS patients]] by buying AIDS drugs at hugely inflated prices and then receiving kickbacks.<ref name=AP29612>[http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-corruption-blamed-aids-non-treatment Ukraine:Corruption blamed for AIDS non-treatment], [[Associated Press]] (29 June 2012)</ref>
In the [[War in Donbass]] the separatist authorities of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]] and [[Luhansk People's Republic]] have banned [[methadone]] and [[substitution therapy]] and have taken a hard line on drug addiction and have banned most international medical organizations.<ref name="RFEaiscaUb"/> As a result, some people living with HIV/AIDS fled separatist-controlled areas, while most remain and suffer even further due to banishment of medical care on the matter in the secessionist-occupied regions.<ref name="RFEaiscaUb">{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/media/photogallery/internally-displaced-women-living-with-hiv/27873176.html |title=HIV: East Ukraine's Silent Crisis|publisher= [[Radio Free Europe]] |date=22 July 2016 }}</ref>
==National response== The National AIDS Committee was established in 1992 but was dissolved in 1998 because of budget disputes. In 1999, the government created the National AIDS Control Coordinating Council under the Cabinet and mandated that all regions establish HIV prevention programs. In 2001, a national plan for combating HIV/AIDS was approved; its goals included preventing the further spread of HIV, developing the capacity to treat infected individuals, and providing social support and counseling for those living with HIV/AIDS.<ref name=usaid/>
Prevention activities have been largely funded by international organizations. Because HIV testing is limited to government facilities, those at greatest risk are not being reached, since marginalized populations are the least likely to use government facilities. Stigma by the medical profession against persons living with HIV/AIDS is a major barrier to accessing information and services.<ref name=usaid/>
The first Ukrainian advocate group of/for Ukrainian AIDS patients was launched on December 10, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/all-ukrainian-network-of-people-living-with-hiv-as-93102.html|title=All-Ukrainian Network of people living with HIV: Association of patients established in Ukraine|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=6 January 2016}}</ref>
==Statistics== Note: all statistics till late 2007. <gallery> File:Modes of HIV transmission in Ukraine in 2007.png|Modes of HIV transmission in Ukraine in 2007 File:Structure of national anti-AIDS spending 2005.jpg|Structure of national anti-AIDS spending in 2005 File:Structure of national anti-AIDS spending 2006.jpg|Structure of national anti-AIDS spending in 2006 </gallery>
== See also == * [[Health in Ukraine]]

М. Эпидемия ВИЧ/СПИДа в Украине: тенденции и последствия, в кн. Демография ВИЧ вып 2, Москва, изд=во МГУ, 2009, под ред. Б. Денисова] {{AIDS}} {{Europe topic|HIV/AIDS in}}
