revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Ray Blanchard | image = Blanchard2008.JPG | caption = Ray Blanchard, 2008 | birth_date = {{BirthDeathAge|B|1945|10|9||||}} | birth_name = Ray Milton Blanchard | birth_place = [[Hammonton, New Jersey]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Canada]] | citizenship = United States, Canada | ethnicity = | fields = [[Psychology]], [[sexology]] | workplaces = [[University of Toronto]]
[[Centre for Addiction and Mental Health]], [[Toronto]] | alma_mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]]
[[University of Illinois]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = [[Kurt Freund]] | doctoral_students = | influences = | influenced = [[J. Michael Bailey]], [[James Cantor]], [[Alice Dreger]], [[Anne Lawrence]] | known_for = [[Blanchard's transsexualism typology]]
[[Fraternal birth order and male sexual orientation|Fraternal birth order effect]]
[[Handedness and sexual orientation]]
[[Erotic target location error]]
Criticism of the [[feminine essence theory of transsexuality]]
Work on [[phallometry]], [[paraphilia]]s, [[gender dysphoria]], [[sexual orientation]] | awards = }} '''Ray Milton Blanchard''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|l|æ|n|tʃ|ər|d}}; born October 9, 1945) is an [[Canadians of American origin|American-Canadian]] [[sexologist]], best known for his research studies on [[pedophilia]], [[transsexualism]], and [[sexual orientation]]. He has also published research studies on [[phallometry]] and several [[paraphilia]]s, including [[transvestism]] and [[erotic asphyxia|autoerotic asphyxia]]. ==Education and career== Blanchard was born in [[Hammonton, New Jersey]]. He received his A.B. in psychology from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1967 and his Ph.D. from the [[University of Illinois]] in 1973. He conducted postdoctoral research at [[Dalhousie University]] until 1976, when he accepted a position as a clinical psychologist at the Ontario Correctional Institute in [[Brampton, Ontario|Brampton, Ontario, Canada]] (a suburb of [[Toronto]]). There, Blanchard met [[Kurt Freund]], who became his mentor. Freund was conducting research in [[chemical castration]] for sex offenders.{{Cite journal | last1 = Freund | first1 = K. | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0447.1980.tb10433.x | title = Therapeutic Sex Drive Reduction | journal = Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica | volume = 62 | pages = 5–38 | year = 1980 | pmid = | pmc = }} In 1980, he joined the [[Clarke Institute of Psychiatry]] (now part of the [[Centre for Addiction and Mental Health]]).{{cite book | editor = Laws RD; O'Donohue WT | title = Sexual Deviance: Theory, Assessment, and Treatment | publisher = [[Guilford Press]] | isbn = 978-1-57230-241-9 | year = 1997 }} In 1995 Blanchard was named Head of Clinical Sexology Services in the Law and Mental Health Programme of the CAMH, where he served until 2010. He is an adjunct Professor of Psychiatry at the [[University of Toronto]].{{cite web | date = 2014 | title = Ray Blanchard, Ph.D., Professor of Psychiatry, University of Toronto | work = utoronto.ca | url = http://individual.utoronto.ca/ray_blanchard/ | accessdate = 2 January 2016}} He served on the [[American Psychiatric Association]] [[DSM-IV]] Subcommittee on Gender Identity Disorders{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/BF01542614 | last1 = Bradley | first1 = S. J. | last2 = Blanchard | first2 = R. | last3 = Coates | first3 = S. | last4 = Green | first4 = R. | last5 = Levine | first5 = S. B. | last6 = Meyer-Bahlburg | first6 = H. F. | last7 = Pauly | first7 = I. B. | last8 = Zucker | first8 = K. J. | title = Interim report of the DSM-IV Subcommittee on Gender Identity Disorders | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 20 | issue = 4 | pages = 333–343 | year = 1991 | pmid = 1953325 }} and was named to the DSM-5 committee. According to the [[Web of Science]], Blanchard's scientific articles have been cited more than 1800 times, with an [[h-index]] of 27.[[Web of Science]], accessed March 18, 2010 ==Fraternal birth order effect== Blanchard has conducted research on [[biology and sexual orientation|factors that influence the development of sexual orientation]], including biological factors. He has proposed a theory known as a [[Fraternal birth order and male sexual orientation|fraternal birth order effect]] or older brother effect. This theory is that the more older brothers a man has, the greater the probability is that he will have a [[Homosexuality|homosexual]] [[sexual orientation]]. The number of older ''sisters'' has no effect, however. The same is not true for lesbians—neither the number of older brothers nor the number of older sisters appears to be related to the sexual orientation of women.{{Cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Bogaert | first2 = A. F. | title = Homosexuality in men and number of older brothers | journal = The American Journal of Psychiatry | volume = 153 | issue = 1 | pages = 27–31 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8540587 | doi=10.1176/ajp.153.1.27 }}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/BF02437839 | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Bogaert | first2 = A. F. | title = Biodemographic comparisons of homosexual and heterosexual men in the Kinsey Interview Data | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 25 | issue = 6 | pages = 551–579 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8931880 }}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0021932098005112 | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Zucker | first2 = K. J. | last3 = Siegelman | first3 = M. | last4 = Dickey | first4 = R. | last5 = Klassen | first5 = P. | title = The relation of birth order to sexual orientation in men and women | journal = Journal of Biosocial Science | volume = 30 | issue = 4 | pages = 511–519 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9818557 }} The fraternal birth order effect has been described by one of its proponents as "the most consistent biodemographic correlate of sexual orientation in men",{{Cite journal | last1 = Bogaert | first1 = A. F. | title = Biological versus nonbiological older brothers and men's sexual orientation | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0511152103 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 103 | issue = 28 | pages = 10771–10774 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16807297 | pmc =1502306 }} with each older brother increasing a man's odds of being gay by about 33%.{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1023/A:1014031201935 | last1 = Cantor | first1 = J. M. | last2 = Blanchard | first2 = R. | last3 = Paterson | first3 = A. D. | last4 = Bogaert | first4 = A. F. | title = How many gay men owe their sexual orientation to fraternal birth order? | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | pages = 63–71 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11910793 }} Blanchard hypothesizes that the older brother effect is caused by interactions between a male fetus and the immune system of the mother: Because certain proteins (called H-y antigens) are produced by male and not by female fetuses, the mother's immune system reacts only to male fetuses and is more likely to produce a reaction with each successive exposure to a male fetus.{{Cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Klassen | first2 = P. | doi = 10.1006/jtbi.1996.0315 | title = H-Y Antigen and Homosexuality in Men | journal = Journal of Theoretical Biology | volume = 185 | issue = 3 | pages = 373–378 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9156085 | pmc = | citeseerx = 10.1.1.602.8423 }} ==Typology of transsexualism== {{main|Blanchard's transsexualism typology}} Blanchard coined the term "autogynephilia" to describe [[Trans woman|trans women]] with an erotic desire "to be women," and hypothesized that all gender dysphoria experienced by this group is of two types: "homosexual" gender dysphoria and "non-homosexual" gender dysphoria. Blanchard defined the former as being present in [[transsexuals]] attracted to men, while he defined the latter as being present in transsexuals attracted to the idea of themselves as women.{{Cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | title = The classification and labeling of nonhomosexual gender dysphorias | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 315–334 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2673136 | doi=10.1007/BF01541951 }} Within the [[transgender]] community the idea has been criticized.{{Cite journal | last1 = Dreger | first1 = A. D. | title = The Controversy Surrounding ''The Man Who Would Be Queen'': A Case History of the Politics of Science, Identity, and Sex in the Internet Age | doi = 10.1007/s10508-007-9301-1 | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 37 | issue = 3 | pages = 366–421 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18431641 | pmc =3170124 }} Blanchard's findings and research have been rejected by the [[World Professional Association for Transgender Health]] (WPATH), the largest association of medical professionals who provides care for transsexual people, as lacking empirical evidence.{{Cite journal | last1 = Gijs | first1 = L. | last2 = Carroll | first2 = R. A. | doi = 10.1080/15532739.2010.550766 | title = Should Transvestic Fetishism Be Classified inDSM 5? Recommendations from the WPATH Consensus Process for Revision of the Diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism | journal = International Journal of Transgenderism | volume = 12 | issue = 4 | pages = 189–197 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }}{{Cite journal | last1 = Knudson | first1 = G. | last2 = De Cuypere | first2 = G. | last3 = Bockting | first3 = W. | title = Second Response of the World Professional Association for Transgender Health to the Proposed Revision of the Diagnosis of Transvestic Disorder forDSM5 | doi = 10.1080/15532739.2011.606195 | journal = International Journal of Transgenderism | volume = 13 | pages = 9–12 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }} Blanchard supports [[publicly funded health care|public funding]] of [[sex reassignment surgery]] as an appropriate treatment for transsexual people, as he believes the available evidence supports that the surgery helps them live more comfortably and happily, with high satisfaction rates.{{cite journal | last = Blanchard | first = R | year = 2000 | title = Part II: The case for publicly funded transsexual surgery | journal = Psychiatry Rounds | volume = 4 | issue = 2 |pages = 4–6 | url = http://individual.utoronto.ca/james_cantor/index_files/Blanchard2000.pdf | format = pdf }} Blanchard defined autogynephilic as “a man's paraphilic tendency to be sexually aroused by the thought or image of himself as a woman”.{{Cite journal|last=Veale|first=Jamie|last2=Clarke|first2=David|last3=Lomax|first3=Terri|date=2011|title=Male-to-Female Transsexuals' Impressions of Blanchard's Autogynephilia Theory|url=|journal=International Journal of Transgenderism|page=136|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}} He researched this theory by conducting a test on a sample of 119 MtF transsexuals who submitted an anonymous questionnaire to test if they were autogynephilic or homosexual. Blanchard believed that not all transsexuals fit in the category of “homosexual” and that some were instead autogynephilic transsexuals. Transsexuals who are autogynephilic can be classified as “sexually attracted to females [[Androphilia and gynephilia|gynephilic]], both sexes bisexual, or neither sex [[alloerotic]]”. Those who were autogynephilic lived out their life as men until they decided to transition. On the other hand, those who were considered homosexual transsexuals “[[Androphilia and gynephilia|androphilia]]” and were sexually attracted to men, were born feminine before transition. Blanchard’s goal in his research was to give a better understanding on various manifestations of transsexuality. Many who read his theory criticized it. They defined autogynephilia as a psychological theory that undermines trans women’s identities.{{Cite web|url=http://juliaserano.blogspot.com/2013/10/in-defense-of-partners.html|title=In Defense of partners|last=Serano|first=Julia|date=2013-10-08|website=Whipping Girl|publisher=|access-date=}} Those who participated in his survey felt that they were neither homosexual nor autogynephilic transsexuals and should not be classified in either group. A majority felt that the sexual attraction to become a women weakened with age, but others reported that they had noticed a change after physical transition. Blanchard ultimately concluded that transsexuals were either sexually aroused by men, androphilic, or aroused by the thought of being a women, nonandrophilic. The number of openly transgender women has rapidly increased over the past several decades. More and more individuals have undergone operations and hormone therapy to completely transition into women.{{Cite journal|last=Lawrence|first=Anne. A|date=2007|title=Becoming What We Love: autogynephilic transsexualism conceptualized as an expression of romantic love|url=|journal=Perspectives in Biology and Medicine|pages=507–508|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}} They believe that their gender identity, defined as “one’s inner sense of being male or female, masculine or feminine”,{{Cite journal|last=Lawrence|first=Anne. A|date=2004|title=. Autogynephilia: A Paraphilic Model of Gender Identity Disorder|url=|journal=Transgender Subjectivities|page=76|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}} did not match the body they were in. According to Blanchard, “Autogynephilic transsexuals were men who were also sexually attracted to women, but whose paraphilic sexual interest made them want to go farther and permanently change their bodies to become the objects of their attraction”. ==The term ''teleiophilia''== Blanchard coined the term ''teleiophilia'' to refer to a sexual preference for adults.{{cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Barbaree | first2 = H. E. | last3 = Bogaert | first3 = A. F. | last4 = Dickey | first4 = R. | last5 = Klassen | first5 = P. | last6 = Kuban | first6 = M. E. | display-authors = etal | year = 2000 | title = Fraternal birth order and sexual orientation in pedophiles | doi = 10.1023/A:1001943719964 | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 29 | issue = 5| pages = 463–478 }} Unlike the terms referring to sexual interest in other age groups, such as [[pedophilia]] (sexual interest in prepubescent children), teleiophilia is not considered a paraphilia. The term was formalized in order to forestall neologisms, such as "adultophilia" or "normophilia," that were occasionally used, but had no precise definition. The term is used primarily by professional sexologists in the scientific literature. ==DSM-5== ===Appointment=== Blanchard served on the gender dysphoria sub-working group for the DSM-IV and served as Chair of the paraphilia sub-working group for the [[DSM-5]]. Activists protested the latter appointment.{{cite news | last = Rau | first = K | date = 2008-07-07 | accessdate = 2012-02-10 | url = http://www.xtra.ca/public/viewstory.aspx?AFF_TYPE=3&STORY_ID=5074&PUB_TEMPLATE_ID=2 | title = Trans activists infuriated by doctors in charge of gender identity definitions | work = [[Xtra!]] }} The [[National Gay and Lesbian Task Force]] issued a statement questioning the APA's decision to appoint Blanchard.{{cite web | publisher = [[National Gay and Lesbian Task Force]] | date = 2008-05-28 | url = http://www.thetaskforce.org/press/releases/pr_052808 | title = Task Force questions critical appointments to APA's Committee on Sexual and Gender Identity Disorders | accessdate = 2012-02-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110302024605/http://www.thetaskforce.org/press/releases/pr_052808|archivedate=2 March 2011}} ===Paraphilias {{anchor|Pedophilia and hebephilia}}=== In 2008, Blanchard was the lead author of an influential paper proposing the introduction of [[hebephilia]] in the DSM-5.{{Cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | last2 = Lykins | first2 = A. D. | last3 = Wherrett | first3 = D. | last4 = Kuban | first4 = M. E. | last5 = Cantor | first5 = J. M. | last6 = Blak | first6 = T. | last7 = Dickey | first7 = R. | last8 = Klassen | first8 = P. E. | title = Pedophilia, Hebephilia, and the DSM-V | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 335–350 | year = 2009 | pmid = 18686026 | doi = 10.1007/s10508-008-9399-9 }} The paper, coauthored mostly with colleagues from CAMH and the University of Toronto, triggered a number of reactions, many of them critical on the basis that it pathologizes reproductively valid behavior in order to uphold current social and legal standards. Critics include [[Richard Green (sexologist)|Richard Green]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Green | first1 = R. | title = Sexual preference for 14-year-olds as a mental disorder: you can't be serious!! (letter to the editor) | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 39 | issue = 3 | pages = 585–586 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20204488 | doi = 10.1007/s10508-010-9602-7 }} DSM-IV editor [[Michael First]],{{cite news | title = DSM-V Work on Paraphilias Begins in Earnest | last = Frieden | first = J | date = 2009-12-01 | work = Clinical Psychiatry News | url = http://psych.imng.com/fileadmin/content_pdf/cpn/archive_pdf/vol37iss12/70438_main.pdf | format = pdf | accessdate = 2013-08-28 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141221061358/http://psych.imng.com/fileadmin/content_pdf/cpn/archive_pdf/vol37iss12/70438_main.pdf | archivedate = 2014-12-21 | df = }} forensic psychologist Karen Franklin,{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1002/bsl.934| title = Hebephilia: Quintessence of diagnostic pretextuality| year = 2010| last1 = Franklin| first1 = K.| journal = Behavioral Sciences & the Law| volume = 28| issue = 6| pages = 751–768| pmid = 21110392}} and [[Charles Allen Moser]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Moser | first1 = C. | title = When is an Unusual Sexual Interest a Mental Disorder? (letter to the editor) | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 323–325 | year = 2009 | pmid = 18946730 | doi = 10.1007/s10508-008-9436-8 }} while others including [[William O'Donohue]] argued that the proposal did not go far enough.{{Cite journal | last1 = O’Donohue | first1 = W. | title = A Critique of the Proposed DSM-V Diagnosis of Pedophilia (letter to the editor) | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 39 | issue = 3 | pages = 587–590 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20204487 | doi = 10.1007/s10508-010-9604-5 }} Blanchard also wrote the literature review paper for the DSM-5 committee regarding pedophilia, in which he summarized and attempted to address the criticism over the [[DSM-IV-TR]] definition of pedophilia.{{Cite journal | last1 = Blanchard | first1 = R. | title = The DSM Diagnostic Criteria for Pedophilia | doi = 10.1007/s10508-009-9536-0 | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 39 | url = http://www.dsm5.org/Documents/Sex%20and%20GID%20Lit%20Reviews/Paraphilias/DSMV.PEDO.pdf | format = pdf | issue = 2 | pages = 304–316 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19757012 | pmc = }} The DSM-5 diagnosis initially proposed a new name ("pedohebophilic disorder") and the rationale for the change cited several of Blanchard's scientific publications.{{cite web|url=http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/Pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=186 |title=U 03 Pedophilic Disorder - Rationale |publisher=[[American Psychiatric Association]] |accessdate=2012-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215165810/http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/Pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=186 |archivedate=February 15, 2010 }} In the end, the ''pedohebephilic disorder'' proposal was rejected, but the name was changed from ''pedophilia'' to ''pedophilic disorder'', reflecting the DSM-5's general distinction between [[paraphilia]] and [[paraphilic disorder]].{{cite journal | author = Blanchard, R. | year = 2013 | title = A dissenting opinion on DSM-5 pedophilic disorder | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 42 | issue = 5 | pages = 675–678 | doi=10.1007/s10508-013-0117-x | pmid=23677282}} Blanchard noted that both Richard Green{{Cite journal | last1 = Green | first1 = R. | title = Is pedophilia a mental disorder? | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 31 | issue = 6 | pages = 467–471; discussion 471–510 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12462476 | doi = 10.1023/A:1020699013309 }} and William O'Donohue{{Cite journal | last1 = O'Donohue | first1 = W. | last2 = Regev | first2 = L. G. | last3 = Hagstrom | first3 = A. | title = Problems with the DSM-IV diagnosis of pedophilia | journal = Sexual Abuse : A Journal of Research and Treatment | volume = 12 | issue = 2 | pages = 95–105 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10872239 | doi=10.1023/A:1009586023326 }} remarked that a so-called "contended pedophile"—an individual who fantasizes about having sex with a child, but does not commit [[child sexual abuse]], but just masturbates fantasizing it, and who does not feel subjectively distressed afterward—does not meet the [[DSM-IV-TR]] criteria for pedophilia, because he does not meet [[Pedophilia#Diagnostic criteria|Criterion B]]. Whereas Green proposed to solve the problem by removing pedophilia from the DSM, and O'Donohue proposed to remove criterion B for pedophilia, Blanchard proposed a general solution applicable to all paraphilias, namely a distinction between paraphilia and ''paraphilic disorder''. The latter term is proposed to identify the [[mental disorder|diagnosable condition]], which meets both Criterion A and B, whereas an individual who does not meet Criterion B, can be ascertained, but ''not'' diagnosed, as having a paraphilia. (Blanchard acknowledges [[Kenneth Zucker]] and [[James Cantor]] for discussions about this distinction). Interviewed by [[bioethics]] professor [[Alice Dreger]], Blanchard explained: "We tried to go as far as we could in depathologizing mild and harmless paraphilias, while recognizing that severe paraphilias that distress or impair people or cause them to do harm to others are validly regarded as disorders."{{cite web | last = Dreger | first = A | date = 2010-02-19 | url = http://www.thehastingscenter.org/Bioethicsforum/Post.aspx?id=4494 | title = Of Kinks, Crimes, and Kinds: The Paraphilias Proposal for the DSM-5 | publisher = [[Hastings Center]] | accessdate = 2012-02-10 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://individual.utoronto.ca/ray_blanchard Blanchard Faculty Webpage] at the University of Toronto *[http://www.psychiatry.utoronto.ca/people/ray-blanchard/ Blanchard Webpage] via Department of Psychiatry *[http://www.psych.org/MainMenu/Research/DSMIV/DSMV/WorkGroups/SexualGID/RayBlanchardPhD.aspx Ray Blanchard profile] via American Psychiatric Association *[http://www.autogynephilia.org/origins.htm Origins of the Concept of Autogynephilia] – Written by Blanchard in February 2004 *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nQKXiZc3FXg Ray Blanchard discusses gay brother studies] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PXlczn2sMbM How and why do older brothers influence sexual orientation in men?] *[https://www.gayout.com/dr.-ray-blanchard Interview with Dr. Ray Blanchard] *[http://ai.eecs.umich.edu/people/conway/TS/BaileyAssociates/BlanchardResigns.html A discussion of the Bailey and Blanchard controversy in HBIGDA] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blanchard, Ray}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American sexologists]] [[Category:Sexual orientation and medicine]] [[Category:Transgender and medicine]] [[Category:People from Hammonton, New Jersey]] [[Category:University of Illinois alumni]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania alumni]] [[Category:American psychologists]]

{{citation style|date=June 2011}} [[File:RonaldNaarPetrusBanden.jpg|thumb|The grave of Ronald Naar at the {{ill|Petrus Banden Cemetery|nl|Begraafplaats Sint Petrus Banden}}, the Hague]] '''Ronald Edwin Naar''' (19 April 1955 – 22 May 2011) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[mountaineer]] known as the [[Netherlands]]' most famous adventurer.{{by whom|date=January 2017}}
Naar was born in [[The Hague]], and was an active climber from the 1970s onwards. He made the first ascents of [[Peak 6393]] in the [[Karakorum]], [[Djo Drake]] in [[Bhutan]], [[Tilleketinda]] on [[Greenland]] and [[Duivelsei]] in [[Surinam]]. He made the first Dutch ascents of several mountains, including the [[Eiger]] (north face) and [[K2]], and was the first Dutch climber to complete the [[Seven Summits]].
He wrote several books about climbing.
He was criticized internationally because in 1992, high on the flanks of [[Mount Everest]] he ordered his expedition to do nothing to assist a dying Indian climber, 30 meters away from their tent camp.<ref>JOE SIMPSON. Dead Man Waving, page 201-210 in ''THE ALPINE JOURNAL'' 1998</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mountaineersbooks.org/Dark-Shadows-Falling-P106.aspx |website=www.mountaineersbooks.org|title=Dark Shadows Falling|accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref><ref>Ronald Naar, 1992, Alleen de top telt, Verslag van de succesvolle expeditie naar de hoogste top ter wereld</ref> Naar answered his critics in ''Leven en dood op de Mount Everest'', (2004, Life and death on Mount Everest)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiking-site.nl/boekrecensies_sa_led.php|title= Boekrecensie |website=www.hiking-site.nl |language=Dutch}}</ref>
Naar died himself while climbing on [[Cho Oyu]] in [[Tibet]] at an altitude of around 8000 metres (26,200 feet) after becoming unwell.
== References == {{Reflist}} *[http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2011/05/dutch_mountaineer_ronald_naar.php Dutch mountaineer Ronald Naar dies during China climb], DutchNews.nl, May 23, 2011 *[http://www.ronaldnaar.nl/ Ronaldnaar.nl]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Naar, Ronald}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch mountain climbers]] [[Category:Mountaineering deaths]] [[Category:Summiters of the Seven Summits]] [[Category:People from The Hague]] [[Category:People associated with the Eiger]]

signedpresident = [[George H. W. Bush]] | signeddate = November 28, 1990 | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} '''Safe Medical Device Amendments of 1990''' or '''Safe Medical Devices Act''' sanctioned progressive reporting and tracking rules for medical devices classified by the [[Medical Device Regulation Act]]. The Act mandates reporting requirements by medical device manufacturers regarding adverse safety events and product effectiveness of devices classified as substantially equivalent to Class III medical devices. The [[United States Statutes at Large|United States Statute]] established the Health and Human Services Office of International Relations and a U.S. Food and Drug Administration office for regulatory activities concerning healthcare products which are considered a combinational biological, device, or drug product.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalhealth.gov |title=Office of Global Affairs |website=International Relations Division |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/CombinationProducts/ |title=Combination Products |website=Office of Combination Products |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration}}</ref> The [[Act of Congress]] transferred the electronic product radiation control provisions established by the [[Radiation Control for Health and Safety Act of 1968|Radiation Control for Health and Safety Act]].
Congressman [[Henry A. Waxman]] and Senator [[Edward M. Kennedy]] were the chairperson sponsors of the safe medical device amendments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d101:HR03095: |title=H.R.3095: Safe Medical Devices Act of 1990 |author=101st U.S. Congress |date=August 2, 1989 |work=U.S. House of Representative Bill Summary & Status |publisher=Library of Congress THOMAS |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> The H.R. 3095 [[legislation]] was passed by the 101st Congressional session and enacted by the [[List of Presidents of the United States|41st President of the United States]] [[George H.W. Bush]] on November 28, 1990.
==History== The 1990 Safe Medical Device law originated after an eight year U.S. congressional inquiry of the Medical Device Amendments of 1976. The 1976 legislation deviated the clarification and proper evaluation of competitive or "substantial equivalence" medical devices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/GuidanceDocuments/ucm073752.htm |title=Use of Standards in Substantial Equivalence Determinations |date=March 12, 2000 |work=Device Advice: Comprehensive Regulatory Assistance |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=March 23, 2013}}</ref>
The U.S. [[General Accounting Office]] presented exhibits for the legislative review which defined the vulnerabilities of the 510K premarket notification process. The 510K premarket approval program was cross-examined to discover qualified medical devices were disallowed from testing in some instances, inadequately tested in a clinical setting, and deficient in adverse data collection oversight.<ref name="510K">{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/HowtoMarketYourDevice/PremarketSubmissions/PremarketNotification510k/ |title=Premarket Notification (510k) |date=September 3, 2010 |work=Device Advice: Comprehensive Regulatory Assistance |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=March 20, 2013}}</ref>
The U.S. congressional review concluded medical devices would require actual device experience in a clinical setting and sufficient reporting of adverse data events. The legislation would encompass medical devices demonstrating the potential for life threatening events and accurate adverse data collection would be required for informed regulatory decisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/10/1/192.full.pdf |title=Safe Medical Devices Act Of 1990 |author=Samuel, Jr., Frank E |year=1991 |work=Health Affairs, 10, no.1 (1991):192-195 |series=At the Intersection of Health, Health Care and Policy |publisher=Health Affairs |location= |page=3-4 |accessdate=March 18, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://www.gao.gov/assets/150/140660.pdf |title=Health Care: Federal Regulation of Medical Devices--Problems Still To Be Overcome |date=September 30, 1983 |website=[http://www.gao.gov/products/HRD-83-53 U.S. GAO:Office of Public Affairs] |publisher=U.S. Government Accountability Office |OCLC=226405143}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.gao.gov/assets/150/146841.pdf |title=Medical Devices: FDA's 510(k) Operations Could Be Improved |date=August 17, 1988 |website=[http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO/PEMD-88-14 U.S. GAO:Office of Public Affairs] |publisher=U.S. Government Accountability Office |OCLC=18759600}}

revision.text:
In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], [[self-employment]] is an option for disabled people. Of those in paid work, 18 per cent of disabled men and 8 per cent of disabled women are self-employed as their main job, compared to only 14 per cent and 6 per cent of non-disabled men and women respectively.<ref>Boylan, A. and Burchardt, T. (2002) Barriers to self-employment for disabled people, Report for the Small Business Service, available at http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file38357.pdf, last accessed January 2010</ref> Many disabled people are not familiar with the rules regarding self-employed work.<ref>Boylan, A. and Burchardt, T. (2002) Barriers to self-employment for disabled people, Report for the Small Business Service, available at http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file38357.pdf, last accessed January 2010</ref> Self-employment is also sometimes the only option for some disabled people who may require flexible working patterns as a result of their impairment.<ref>Association of Disabled Professionals (2007) 'Setting Up In Business? A Resource Guide for Disabled People and their Advisors', ADP, availability details at http://www.adp.org.uk/news.php</ref>
==UK self-employment and benefits== Being at a disadvantage in the [[wiktionary:Workplace|workplace]] means one is more likely to be isolated from the rest of [[society]]: to be socially excluded. UK policy has created a number of different programmes which have the aim of addressing [[social exclusion]] through [[employment]],<ref>http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/DisabledPeople/Employmentsupport/WorkSchemesAndProgrammes/DG_187696</ref> including self-employment. One example, which aims to address the additional barriers disabled people face, is the [http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/DisabledPeople/Employmentsupport/WorkSchemesAndProgrammes/DG_4000347 Access to Work] programme, which may provide impairment related equipment, support worker and travel costs if the disabled person is unable to use public transport.
There are also opportunities to work whilst claiming some benefits, such as [http://www.dwp.gov.uk/employment-and-support/ Employment and Support Allowance] and [https://web.archive.org/web/20100124152536/http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/dptctables/index.htm Disabled Persons Tax Credit]. For example, [[Employment and Support Allowance]] (ESA) allows disabled people to do some (‘Permitted’) work, which includes self-employment, not only as a route to independence, but also to ‘allow them to be socially included’.<ref>DWP (2008) Technical Factsheet T3: Permitted Work, Voluntary Work and Test Trading Rules, {{cite web|url=http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718212004/http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}</ref> This 'permitted work' must satisfy a number of criteria.<ref>DWP (2008) Technical Factsheet T3: Permitted Work, Voluntary Work and Test Trading Rules, {{cite web|url=http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718212004/http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}</ref> For example, if a disabled person’s [[income]] is less than £20 per week, they can work any number of hours whilst still claiming ESA.<ref>DWP (2008) Technical Factsheet T3: Permitted Work, Voluntary Work and Test Trading Rules, {{cite web|url=http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718212004/http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/t3_current_work.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>Welfare Reform Act 2007 available at http://www.opsi.gov.uk/Acts/acts2007/pdf/ukpga_20070005_en.pdf</ref> <ref>Disability Alliance (2009) Factsheet: Work for people who are sick or disabled, {{cite web|url=http://www.disabilityalliance.org/f35.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215033022/http://www.disabilityalliance.org/f35.htm |archivedate=2009-12-15 |df= }}</ref> Income-related ESA is non-taxable whilst contribution-based ESA is taxable.<ref>Low incomes Tax Reform Group http://www.litrg.org.uk/low-income-workers/state-benefits#esai</ref>
== Universal credit== Under universal credit, if a disabled person is gainfully self-employed then a minimum level of income from self-employment will be assumed, even if the actual income is lower than this. This minimum level of income will not apply {{Citation needed|reason=needs reference to a policy paper or decision|date=December 2013}} to anyone who is found to have a limited capability for work, following a work capability assessment. This minimum level of income is determined by the claimant’s individual circumstances, so long as a self-employed person's profits allow them to pay themselves more than the minimum wage. Income is calculated by the number of hours a claimant is expected to work multiplied by the National Minimum Wage. Some self-employed people with low profits will not necessarily be in a position to pay themselves this minimum wage. Thus, the hours a person are expected to work and the assumed income level will reflect the circumstances of self-employed people only if their profits bring in more than the minimum wage. This will not always be the case if/when profits are low.
Disabled self-employed claimants will still be subject to universal credit self-reporting requirements.{{Citation needed|reason=needs reference to a policy paper or decision|date=August 2017}} Universal credit is said{{Citation needed|reason=needs reference to a policy paper or decision|date=August 2017}} to encourage disabled people to take self-employment as a route to independence and social inclusion, providing it is the right path for them and providing that the standard 'expected' hours and 'assumed' income levels are not applied{{Citation needed|reason=needs reference to a policy paper or decision|date=August 2017}}.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.adp.org.uk Association of Disabled Professionals] * [http://www.disabilityalliance.org Disability Alliance] * [http://www.disabled-entrepreneurs.net/ Disabled Entrepreneurs’ Network] *[http://www.lcdisability.org/ Leonard Cheshire Disability] * [http://www.litrg.org.uk/ Low Incomes Tax Reform Group]
[[Category:Disability in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Employment in the United Kingdom]]

{{For|the American TV channel formerly known as Telecare|Catholic Faith Network}} {{refimprove|date=February 2010}} '''Telecare''' is the term for offering remote care of elderly and physically less able people, providing the care and reassurance needed to allow them to remain living in their own homes. The use of [[sensors]] may be part of a package which can provide support for people with illnesses such as [[dementia]], or people at risk of falling.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Perez |first1=David |last2=Memeti |first2=Suejb |last3=Pllana |first3=Sabri |title=A simulation study of a smart living IoT solution for remote elderly care |url=https://doi.org/10.1109/FMEC.2018.8364069 |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref>
Most telecare mitigates harm by reacting to untoward events and raising a help response quickly. Some telecare, such as [[Safety Confirmation|safety confirmation]] and lifestyle monitoring have a preventive function in that a deterioration in the telecare user's wellbeing can be spotted at an early stage.
Telecare is specifically different from [[telemedicine]] and [[telehealth]]. Telecare refers to the idea of enabling people to remain independent in their own homes by providing person-centred technologies to support the individual or their [[carers]].
Mobile telecare is an emerging service where state of the art mobile devices with roaming SIMs are utilised to allow a client to go outside their home but still have a 24/7 telecare service available to support them. Typical devices that do this are such things as the [http://www.hoip-telecom.com Pebbell] mobile GPS tracker.
The meaning and usage of the term 'telecare' has not yet settled into consistent use. In the UK it is grounded in the social care framework and focuses on the meaning described above. In other countries 'telecare' may be applied to the practice of healthcare at a distance.
==Uses of Telecare== In its simplest form, it can refer to a fixed or mobile telephone with a connection to a monitoring centre through which the user can raise an alarm. Technologically more advanced systems use sensors, whereby a range of potential risks can be monitored. These may include falls, as well as environmental changes in the home such as floods, fire and gas leaks. Carers of people with dementia may be alerted if the person leaves the house or other defined area. When a sensor is activated it sends a radio signal to a central unit in the user's home, which then automatically calls a 24-hour monitoring centre where trained operators can take appropriate action, whether it be contacting a local key holder, doctor or the emergency services.
Telecare also comprises standalone telecare which does not send signals to a response centre but supports carers through providing local (in-house) alerts in a person's home to let the carer know when a person requires attention.
It is important to note that 'telecare' is not just a warning system if someone strays from home but is also preventative measure whereby people are brought back and kept in the community through regular communication. There are now a large range of telecare services available with some of the most well known being the pendant alarm, mobile carephone system, [[pill dispenser]], telephone prompt service the movement monitoring, fall detector and more. Multi-lingual telecare services have now been introduced opening the service up to a wider audience. All play a role in maintaining people's independence and allowing people to stay in their own homes.
==The future of Telecare== Technological advances result in the possibility of promoting independence and for providing care from the social initiative sector, which now contemplates [[eCare]], and navigation/positioning systems, such as [[GPS]] for people with dementia or other cognitive impairments.
==Telecare in the UK== In 2005 the UK's Department of Health published ''Building Telecare in England'' to coincide with the announcement of a grant to help encourage its take up by local councils with social care responsibilities.<ref>[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_4115303 Building Telecare in England]</ref>
The UK’s Department of Health’s Whole System Demonstrator (WSD)<ref>[http://www.dh.gov.uk/prod_consum_dh/groups/dh_digitalassets/documents/digitalasset/dh_100947.pdf Whole Systems Demonstrators: An Overview of Telecare and Telehealth]</ref> launched in May 2008. It is the largest randomised control trial of [[telehealth]] and telecare in the world, involving 6191 patients and 238 GP practices across three sites, [[London Borough of Newham|Newham]], [[Kent]] and [[Cornwall]]. The trials were evaluated by: [[City University London]], [[University of Oxford]], [[University of Manchester]], [[Nuffield Trust]], [[Imperial College London]] and [[London School of Economics]].
The WSD headline findings after the telehealth trial, involving 3154 patients, included these outcomes:<ref>[http://www.bmj.com/content/344/bmj.e3874 Effect of telehealth on use of secondary care and mortality: findings from the Whole System Demonstrator cluster randomised trial]</ref>
* 45% reduction in mortality rates * 20% reduction in emergency admissions * 15% reduction in A&E visits * 14% reduction in elective admissions * 14% reduction in bed days * 8% reduction in tariff costs
The telecare findings were supposed to be published at some point in the future.<ref>[http://3millionlives.co.uk/about-telehealth-and-telecare#bmj_whole_system_demonstrator_paper BMJ Whole System Demonstrator Paper]</ref> In fact they have never surfaced. Some patients are still hopeful that telecare will lead to substantial improvements in the quality of services.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vinegar|first1=Dick|title=Telecare: what's happened to the whole system demonstrators?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2012/apr/10/telecare-whole-system-demonstrators-wsd|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=10 April 2012}}</ref> The research showed that the telecare approach was not cost effective, with an incremental cost per [[QALY]] when added to usual care of £92,000.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henderson|first1=Catherine|title=Cost effectiveness of telehealth for patients with long term conditions (Whole Systems Demonstrator telehealth questionnaire study): nested economic evaluation in a pragmatic, cluster randomised controlled trial|journal=British Medical Journal|date=22 March 2013|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/346/bmj.f1035|accessdate=17 October 2014}}</ref>
The Government's Care Services minister, Paul Burstow, stated in 2012 that [[telehealth]] and telecare would be extended over the next five years (2012-2017) to reach three million people.<ref>[http://www.dh.gov.uk/health/2012/01/roll-out-of-telehealth-and-telecare-to-benefit-three-million-lives/ 3 Million Lives Announcement]</ref> This ambition was formally abandoned in November 2013. In September 2014 [[NHS England]] announced a replacement, but much lower profile, new “technology enabled care services” programme.<ref>{{cite news|title=NHS England outlines successor to telehealth programme|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/technology/nhs-england-outlines-successor-to-telehealth-programme/5074984.article#.VEGCsivFuKI|accessdate=17 October 2014|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=23 September 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Assistive technology]] *[[Wandering (dementia)]]
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.isft.net/ International Society for Telemedicine & eHealth] *
[[Category:Telecommunication services]] [[Category:Welfare]] [[Category:Telehealth]] [[Category:Health informatics]]
